Adults can learn how to let go and take chances and the lesson children could learn is that no matter how strong you think you are you'll always need parent figures in your life.
All the characters are amazing and their voice actors, but Dory takes the spotlight in this movie. Between her forgetting everything and being such a cute and lovable fish, you just have to like her. We can't forget about the person who gave life to Dory, Ellen DeGeneres was absolutely amazing in this movie.
This is another classic Pixar movie that stands the test of time and proves why Pixar is one of the best animation studios. This is a must-watch film for everyone.

reviews.review_title: Quite possibly the best film of 2003!
reviews.content: This film proves that animated and computer-generated films are not just forchildren.  The story is compelling, the voice acting is amazing, the visuals are stunning... Ellen DeGeneres is fantastic as Dory.  It's a great film for the whole family.

I took my three children, ages 2, 4 and 8 to see this film. They really enjoyed it - there was enough humor to keep them engaged and the bright colors and fun characters kept them watching instead of fidgeting as they do at lesser family fare. What I really liked were the little bits of adult humor sprinkled throughout. The kids found it funny, but the adults actually found it funnier. Disney and Pixar have once again created a fun family film that we won't mind watching over again in the years to come.

Finding Nemo was really a great film for the family but I see Pixar is falling into Disney's dysfunctional family world though- they killed off Nemo's mother right away! What is it with Disney films and their world of single parents? Look at the past films, in Toy Story their was no mention of Andy's father at all, Bambi's mother gets shot, Cinderella's left to her wicked step-family after her parents die, Aladdin had no parents, Jasmine had only her father, the Little Mermaid, where was her mother? the legend of Tarzan was made for Disney with his parents being killed, and the list goes on and on! I would think that parents groups would be screaming their lungs out by now over these films still having the same plot. Me, I think it's funny because it's gotten to where I bet with others on whether the next Disney film will have 1 parent or no parents in it!Besides this the film was great with Ellen DeGeneres obviously being the best part of the whole cast. I've never been much of an Ellen fan but she made me laugh pretty good with her character, Dory the short term memory fish. Great casting with her! In addition I got a kick out of the end credits with the "swim byes" and the interaction of the characters with the end credits rolling.Pixar is on their way to becoming the best family entertainment on the big screen if they keep doing what they've been, but I think that they should separate themselves from Disney's orphan ideology!

reviews.review_title: Good animation makes not a good movie
reviews.content: Allright - the animation and the bgs are cool. Really great pictures of reefs and the marine life. Well, but this is just all. I do not know what film other people have seen, but it must have been a Finding Nemo with a good story and strong characters. The constant action was to much. The beginning of the movie was just horrible - okay, it was not the first time, that characters in Disney-Movies died, but what was good circumnavigated in "Tarzan" when the gorilla baby was killed, in Finding Nemo it was a terrible solution to introduce Coral first with a speaking part and kill her instantly after a talk about the Clown-fish-family, the babies and so on. After this it was not a problem to me that Marlin was overprotective and always wanted the best for his disabled son (why did he need a stunted fin at all?). The biggest probem was Dori - If you ever knew someone who sufferd on Alzheimers disease, you will not find this fish funny - shame on you Pixar, this was not so nice, why couldn´t she just be silly? Bruce and his group was funny, but this did not save it. Most scenes where too tough and nothing for younger Kids - nevertheless it was also boring for adults most of the time. Fish are Friends - not Food - well, but what are the human characters in this movie - Monsters? I did not like this. Overfishing of the seas is one thing, caring for an aquarium another.After this great trailer I expected more from it, better watch good old 2 D Animation next time - there is enough assortment from Studio Ghibli and a lot of Disney Classics to watch.

reviews.review_title: One of the year's best movies, animated or otherwise
reviews.content: Ignore the reviews claiming that "Finding Nemo" is great, but not Pixar Studios' best film. Ignore any comments on this page that point out flaws in the theme, humor, or sentimental plot. In fact, ignore everything you may have read about "Finding Nemo" and just see it for yourself. "Nemo" is Pixar's crowning achievement, and it's as close to perfect as any movie I've ever seen. EVERYTHING works in this film: the vocal performances are top-notch (particularly by Albert Brooks' Marlin and Ellen DeGeneres' Dory), the animation is nothing short of breathtaking, the dialogue is superbly written and genuinely hilarious at times, and the story is wonderfully simple, almost Zen-like. Disney's tendency to go overboard with the sentiment has been thankfully held back, so when an emotional moment comes along, you really feel it. No part of the movie drags, no scene seems out of place, and the entire thing will leave you captivated, whether you're 8 or 80. It's been so long since I've seen an honest-to-God masterpiece come out of the theatre, it might seem like I'm exaggerating, but rest assured: "Finding Nemo" deserves any and all praise it receives. This one's a keeper, folks.

reviews.review_title: Finding Nemo is a remarkable Pixar film.
reviews.content: Finding Nemo is a remarkable Pixar film. A clown fish named Marlin, whose voice is Albert Brooks, family gets destroyed by a barracuda, but one egg survived. Marlin names the egg Nemo, whose voice is Alexander Gould. Marlin devotes his life to make sure Nemo stays protected and safe. Marlin pushes Nemo's limits, and Nemo adventures off in the mysterious ocean. Nemo is than captured by a diver and Marlin starts a search through the frightening ocean to save his son. Marlin runs into a fish name Dory, whose voice is Ellen DeGeneres, which joins him for the search.The movie defines how love and trust can beat all odds. The movie floats back and forth from Nemo and Marlin, as they are determined to reunite. Marlin's obstacles through the dangerous life of the ocean like the deadly encounter with Bruce the shark, angler fish, jellyfishes and a whale, do not stand a chance with that determination of love for his son. Nemo, lost and confused, hears about Marlin's treacherous adventures, influences him to escape.Toy Story and Finding Nemo have much in common. Being produced by the same company, show the animations of animals and toys love for another, is a determination to make it home. The two have many dangerous situations that never stop them from what they seek. The two films are both kid and adult friendly.The film has a colorful picture and everything look so perfect. The computer-animated imagines make you feel as if you are watching through the eyes of a fish. The film has every detail right from the voices matching the personality of the fish, the three dimensional of the animation, the exact flow of water, the reflection of light to the exact swim of the fish. Not only, does the film seem so real, the humor is out of control. Even during the dodgy scenes, the laughs are still there. The wow factor is there all the way through the film.At the end of the film, love reunites the two clown fish and the adventure still does not end. Nemo and Marlin take the lessons they learned to make it home. Marlin trusts Nemo to do things and Nemo learns to respect his father more. Marlin even lives up to the name clown fish. The movie is fantastic for all ages and has moments that will have you saying, keep on swimming, and keep on swimming.

What more can one say about one of the most remarkable studios in Hollywood's history. Despite the profit-munching monolithic beast that is Disney, constantly peering over Pixar's shoulder to ensure profits are aplenty in every new feature, this never seems to distract such a remarkable studio from making pieces of pure art. That is what Finding Nemo is, art. From the glorious animation that brings the South-West Pacific alive on-screen, to the peaceful, pitch-perfect score, combined with the art of creating great characters and story, something that Pixar has always excelled at, creates a beautiful film experience.Finding Nemo is soaked in brilliance. Comedy is something that Pixar has always kept in its films but used fairly sparsely with a merciful aversion to the cheap pop-culture references that the likes of DreamWorks use habitually. That said, Finding Nemo is probably the most prominent example of a Pixar work with so many laugh-out-loud moments. Most of these of course centre around the exquisite Dory, the fish who couldn't remember. Her lapses in short-term memory and confidence in her ability to "speak whale," provide the most glorious moments of comedy I have seen in any film.But no "great" film can survive on comedy alone. Pixar, in every single film have excelled at giving their works heart. Finding Nemo, along with Up (and from what I've heard about Toy Story 3, being in the UK I have yet to have seen it) is Pixar's most heartfelt and moving story. The moment, where Marlon having finally found Nemo, fears he has lost him once more at the bottom of that net, is so incredibly powerful, and for a second you do think "no, surely not." Indeed it does have a happy ending (it is Disney) but that is perfect. Such a heart-breaking ending, although brave would simply have been wrong, however the choking feeling I felt when I saw Nemo tangled, limp and lifeless in that net is testament to the power that Finding Nemo possess and the brilliance that is Pixar. However, for me, the most powerful moment of this film is the ending. With Marlon saying goodbye to his son as he swims off into the ocean, away from his dad, who, since the devastating loss of Nemo's mother at the beginning, has struggled to let his son go, be free and grow-up, we see he has finally reached the point where he can let go, with a soft, introverted "bye son." The emotional punch this packs as "THE END" flashes up as Nemo swims away, is very heavy. The character arc is complete and Marlon himself has come to terms with the pain and suffering of the past, and has moved on.This of course is a human story, with fish. Pixar has made a film about fish that moves us on every human level from comedy to deep tragedy, and this is proof that Finding Nemo is immortal and magnificent.

For a long time, I was (and still am) skeptical about Disney movies, whichever size and shape they come in. About 7 minutes into this one I was saying to myself, "The artwork is amazing, CG (*I'm a computer person, so I yearn for really cool, CPU-intensive CG*) is totally unrivaled, but the story line sucks so bad, why I am watching another Disney tear-squeezer??"Well, looks like after 15 minutes of run time Pixar guys had a brief meeting and said, "Screw you, Disney, we are not letting you ruin another one!"Please -- bear for exactly 15 minutes of the most syrupy kindergarten stuff (stunning visuals will help you, though you might feel guilty about watching this while wide awake, instead, say, shoveling the snow), and watch the 199% predictable slop explode into one of the most ironic, witty, and -- did I mention that? -- beautifully constructed CG cartoons of all time.Did you like "Shrek"? Well, this is not exactly "Shrek" material, but still IMDB 10 grade. Just because IMDB gives you only 10 points to choose from. On a scale of 100, "Shrek" would be 100, and "Nemo" would pull about 92.Just sit back, settle yourselves; I repeat, you'll need to watch the first 15 minutes to grasp the plot (though not necessarily, there's enough redundancy in the dialogs for the late-comers (or the denser crowd)), and enjoy -- really enjoy! -- the rest.You will see a couple of scenes where the Disney managers came back and tried to ruin (sorry, save! of course, save from the hand of perverted Pixarians!) the movie, but these episodes were only mildly irritating and quickly dissolved themselves without overall damage to the spectacular, weird and funny world of talking, blinking, breathing, flirting fish.Worth to watch. Most probably worth to own, if anything, just to watch your favorite little charming scenes again and again.Enjoy, /D

A must-see movie for kids of all ages.Disney/Pixar Studios outdid themselves once again. The animation is flawless and the special effects are astonishing (notice the water, close to the surface). The humor is sharper as ever, similar to the one you saw in Monsters, Inc.The character's voices, specially in the case of Ellen DeGeneres', couldn't be better.Even the soundtrack, composed by Randy Newman's cousin, Tom, is amazing. Robbie Williams' version of Bobby Darin's classic "Beyond the Sea" gives the soundtrack a final touch.10 stars for this one, no doubt about it. If you have kids, take them to the theater to watch it. If you don't, go anyway. You won't regret it.

Finding Nemo is a modern animated masterpieceI found this film thoroughly entertaining from start to finish! First of all the animation was fantastic, truly admirable. When the movie first came out, I immediately began to compare Finding Nemo to other recent animated classics (a la Shrek, Monster's Inc.) and found that it was surely a worthy adversary. Its plot, dialogue, and animation are all very original and Pixar seems to be always striving for a higher goal. Animators didn't simply do what had been done over and over again many times, but came up with something new and fresh to give audiences. And boy does it pay off.
Not to mention Finding Nemo's enormous success in the box office, I have yet to hear someone nay-saying about this movie. This film can be enjoyed by anyone, any age. Animated movies are beginning to evolve to appeal to a variety of audiences, and Finding Nemo is a very good example. The comedic dialogue is hilarious on many levels, for kids and parents alike, which gives it added appeal and all the more fun. I also found the sloo of characters all unique and funny in their own simple way. Dory, Nemo, Marlin, Bruce (the shark), Nigel (the pelican), and Crush (the turtle) are all very different, original, and hilarious characters that bring something differnt to the table. Also, the fact that the writers present several ironies and stereotypes to this characters adds to their hilarity; vegetarian sharks, surfer turtles, clownfish that aren't funny, mindless hungry seagulls, the list can go on and on. In conclusion I found Finding Nemo original, hilarious, and fun for everybody; truly everybody. 4 out of 5.

when compared to the great Disney movies this film is really pathetic. i couldn't wait for it to be over.the script is a long set of clichés. the comedy is so juvenile and stale that if i had seen this at age 10, it's safe to say i wouldn't have laughed at a single part.the animation is ugly. there is something very commercial and impersonal about computer animation. if you want to see beautiful animation, look at the hand-made watercolor backgrounds in the "Jungle Book".if you want to watch a movie with a kid, pick one from when Walt Disney was still alive. they are funny even to adults, if sometimes politically incorrect.

Easily the best Pixar movie. Great music, great direction, GREAT voice acting, great "set" design, great humor, great story, great dialogue, great scenes. The best Pixar movie EVER!Finding Nemo is about a widowered clownfish named Marlin that is over protective over his just-in-school son Nemo. After Nemo gets caught by humans, Marlin goes on a wild seamonkey chase to get him back.EXCELLENT voice acting from Albert Brooks, Ellen DeGeneres, Willem Dafoe, and Alexander Gould. EXCELLENT music from Thomas Newman. The BEST directing of an animated movie EVER!The entire crowd at my theater ABSOLUTELY LOVED IT! No joke fell flat. The tone was perfect, everything was perfect. There's nothing I can say that was bad about it, or even could be improved.10/10

Absolutely amazing movie.  Disney/Pixar have definitely out-done themselves. The animation must get an A++ as well as everything else.  The plot line was great, and they couldn't have picked better actors/actress' for the voices.  A must see. I assure you that you will not be disappointed. I'll be seeing it again for sure.  2 thumbs up! 10 stars!

reviews.review_title: Nothing fishy about it: 'Finding Nemo' is an animated classic
reviews.content: The 21st century has had its share of high-tech enhanced flicks, but the "Lord of the Rings" trilogy and Pixar's "Finding Nemo" have proven that it is the inclusion of compelling characters and wonderful stories that makes for a great movie."Finding Nemo" has everything a discerning moviegoer could hope for. Ellen DeGeneres's Dory and Albert Brooks' Marlin are perfect casting and this movie will lure in audiences of all ages. Hook, line and sinker.

I have just returned from the most exciting movie I've seen in a long time! Finding Nemo is Pixar's BEST movie, replacing Toy Story (I know, I know, but its true) as the most visually imaginative animated movie.  Its funny, DeGeneres is hilarious - her fish is perfectly animated, Brooks is sooooo much better than in the In-Laws, back to his true form - I loved every minute of this film.  The celebrity voices are great; Allison Janney from West Wing is a wonderful starfish, Willem DeFoe, always a seductive voice, is a scar worn Tang, even the movie's creator, Andrew Stanton was greatness as the sea turtle Crush. This is one G rated film that is definitely for everyone, any age, any circumstances - see this alone, on a date, with your family - just go...I was swept away with not knowing what was going to happen next, the colors and visuals and the realisation of the sea - the humour, the storyline (a Dad prevails!) all add up to an A+, #1, Best Picture of the Year achievement.  Applause, applause, applause to Pixar once again!

reviews.review_title: Not Bad, But It's no Toy Story
reviews.content: Finding Nemo was clever, cute, well written and definitely a technical advance in animated story telling.  It doesn't compare, however, to the first Pixar film I viewed - Toy Story.My main complaint is that the story moves through so many locations (if I can use that term for an animated movie), that by the end, everything seems rushed.  While I understand that the whole premise of the story is a journey, the writers might have been better off spending more time in three or four locales, than hurrying through 10+.  That said, my daughter loved it!6/10  (my daughter, 10/10)

reviews.review_title: One of the best children's movie in a long time...
reviews.content: Finding Nemo has some of the best lessons to be learned.  It was maybe a little more personal to me because I have a close relative (child) with a handicap similar to Nemo's.  It has the tragedy (almost as heartwrenching as The Lion King), but it is a sweet, wonderful story about learning how to let go and how to understand and accept other people for who they are.

I saw Finding Nemo today- I've been meaning to see it. I expected a great comedy. I was disappointed.In case you've been living under a rock (or don't have TV) you've probably seen commercials for this. You also probably know that Marlin, a clownfish, has lost his son. With the help of Dory, he is determined to find Nemo, his son.It has lots of colorful characters that I enjoyed watching. Each of the tank fish are equally unique. My favorite is Peach, probably.
The settings are very creative. The EAC is hilarious and imaginative, as well as the Jellyfish Forest.The only problem I had is that is it's only mildly funny. It's awfully sad.The Bottom Line: A wildly creative, mildly funny adventure! Two out of Four Chili Peppers!

The  underwater sequences where spectacular, enriched with bright colors and fantastic effects. The story line was a little to simple for me and yet is probaly the best family adventure of the year with a light humour that gets all of the little kids laughing at every bump of a fish which can get a little irritating at the cinemas.I take pride in being an Australian and it was good to see pixar getting real Australian's to do the voice's instead of some American impersonator's that give Australia a far from reality accent. Even with the Aussie actors the aussie slang was used far to often than what it is in reality. Really, why would a well educated dentist be calling people "sheila" and saying "crikey" and "mate" in every sentence. Anyway sheila is an old school word that only the middle aged bogens use these days. And crikey is Steve Irwins word. Not the best movie ive every seen id say it rate about 7/10

Excellent movie! I'm not a big fan of animation, specially Disney movies, but this one was great! Funny characters (except Marlin, "for a clownfish. he's not that funny"), topped by Ellen DeGeneres as Dory. She has the perfect voice for the part.The story isn't that original (man looking for his son after losing him because of a fight) and parents with really young children might have a problem explaining what happens to Coral at the start of the movie, but the characters that Marlin meets are just hilarious. Sharks, jellyfish turtles, pelicans and seagulls (My favorites: Mine!) all help him out with his quest, or form some obstacle on the way. Must see movie!

I love to watch animated movies. I find them so entertaining, even though most people would say that those types of movies were meant for little kids I don't think that I will ever out grow them. Finding Nemo (2003) directed by Andrew Stanton and Lee Unkrich is in my opinion one of the best movies. Little kids love to watch these animated pictures, they teach kids and help them form an understanding of the world. Most of Pixar films, if not all of Pixar's films have a message in them, something the creator wants us to get out of the film besides watching it for merely our entertainment. Compared to a Disney movie, Pixar pictures have no magic; problems in the movie can't be solved by a wave of a wand or by a fairy godmother. Furthermore, humans are rarely the main characters and most of the films the protagonist is a non human character. In Finding Nemo there are humans in the story however, they play a small role in the film. We also see that in this picture the villain or the antagonist is human for example, Darla, they don't play a big role in the film but they sometimes support the antagonist. In Finding Nemo we see a clown fish, Marlin who is very protective of his only son, Nemo. And with this, already a lot of people can relate. Many parents are overprotective for their child and do not want them to venture out on their own because of the possibility of them getting hurt. Parents are so scared of letting go and letting them explore the world on their own. While watching the film we also see Marlin overcome his fear of the ocean as he travels with Dorothy to find his son. This is probably the most relatable message in the movie with both kids and adults. We all have fears and overcoming them can be really hard but sooner or later we realize that there was nothing to be afraid of. When we see Nemo is stuck in a fish tank at a dentist office Nemo and his new found fish friends try to help him escape. However, it all goes wrong and everyone gave up on the idea because it was dangerous and could've hurt Nemo. But Nemo does not give up he goes and tries again this time succeeding in stopping the water filter. The film attempts to change our lives for the better. For parents its saying that there's a time where you have to let go of your kids being overprotective can be a bad thing and it can lead to your kids getting annoyed/frustrated and refusing to listen to you. For kids, it's to tell them that your parents care and they want to protect you. Also to never give up in anything they do. These messages are universal they apply to everyone around the world. The theme in this film I think is relevant to any parent watching it. Scared of letting go of their kids, being very overprotective, the fear of losing their kids almost every parent can relate to this.

reviews.review_title: This is a great movie with great characters.
reviews.content:
warning: possible spoilers. (But probably not)☼☼☼☼ (Four out of Four Suns)
Finding Nemo is a great movie that will capture your heart with unforgettable characters, great cinematography and something that everyone will love. There are three main characters in this movie: Dory, Marlin, and Nemo. Dory (Ellen Degeneres) is a fish with short-term memory loss that Marlin bumps into while looking for the boat that took Nemo. Her memory-loss is brought up throughout the movie but not in a way that it becomes annoying. Marlin (the father of Nemo) is afraid of the ocean. Marlin is an overdone, overprotected parent but with good reason. When Nemo was still a small egg his mother (Coral) was eaten while trying to protect all the eggs from a fishy predator. In some parts Marlin's fear is burdening while in others it is humorous. Nemo is a small fish with a small fin that causes him to be ridiculed at some times and at others makes it hard for him to do thing like swimming far distances. Disregarding his disablement Nemo wishes to be a normal fish and not always be stunted by his fathers caution.
The minor characters are unforgettable themselves. These characters come in groups. The minor characters most focused on by the script are, what I like to call the tank gang. These characters are first introduced when Nemo is dropped into the fish tank at the dentist's office. The `gang' consists of seven former ocean dwellers, all with quirky characteristics. Bloat the blow fish is just a nice, easy going guy; Deb is a fish who thinks her reflection is her sister named Flo; Peach the starfish from e-bay is the all seeing; Jacque is a French crustacean with a knack for cleaning; Bubbles is, you guessed it, addicted to bubbles. The last fish in the tank gang is Gil. Gill is a fish that greatly reminded me of the people I know who want to help me but are really more interested in helping themselves.
The cinematography of this movie is truly amazing and makes you feel as if you are in the movie. This is definitely one of the best-filmed animated movies I have seen in years. It is obvious that the artists took great care to make the movie as realistic as possible. This is proved when Dory has a nosebleed and the blood moves the way a liquid twirls when squirted into water.All in all Finding Nemo is one of the best movies I have ever seen. I only have one warning for parents: your children may take to repeating all the lines from this movie (I for one know all the lines of the movie). This movie touched my heart and imprinted characters in my brain.  I suggest this movie to all people , even those who don't see animated movies much. My parting words are: Just keep swimming.

Toy Story again, but with fishes.1 idea, 2 movies..... I'm getting really sick of this - GO TAKE A CREATIVE WRITING CLASS, YOU IDIOTS!Yes, but some truly *amazing* visuals, as always - there must be *something* there to make you part with your hard-earned. (and some parts of that something, for some reason, look very much like a screensaver common in Win98 days that I saw here and there... ??!!!! Maybe Pixar look for their inspiration in more mundane (and obvious!) places than I thought?.... :) )Enjoy on TV, friends places and the like. DON'T PART, etc., etc.,....

Finding Nemo is to begin with a movie with stunning visual effects and editing, the perspectives and colors are just amazing. The story is beautiful and relatable even though it is about fish. Clownfish Nemo gets captured by a diver, his father Marlin, is doing everything he can to find his son. He gets the help of Dory, a fish with short term memory loss. Dory is very funny in my opinion. Marlin and Dory travel through dark oceans and colorful reefs all the way to Sydney where Nemo is. To make a long story short: a beautiful film about a strong relationship between father and son. And then lastly, Thomas Newman did an excellent job on the music score. The music fits the visuals perfectly and it really calls on the intended emotions i think. Finding Nemo is my all time favorite movie. I can never have enough of it.

Okay, I admit it, I am a Disney fan, so deal with it.
That being said, "Finding Nemo" was one of the most enjoyable shows I have seen in a long time.  I found the story line to be very well written, and extremely tight, with very little dead time on the screen.There characters were superb, the graphics stunning and the ending so very typically Disney (not a bad thing.)  I found myself smiling and laughing throughout the show.This one is great for the kids, yet still entertaining for the adults!The Crazed Viking

There's no way this movie is better than "The Deer Hunter," "Notorious," or any of the other movies that have recently been edged out of the top 100 list. It was a nice movie, the animation was very fluid, and I wasn't bored, and that's about all I can say in favor of it. If you want even the slightest intellectual stimulation, search elsewhere, but if you're interested in having a basic message pounded into your head throughout the course of the an hour and a half, then by all means give it a try.

My 19 year old daughter kept telling me to see this that I would enjoy it and she was right. It was perfectly entertaining for an adult female in her early fifties even without the excuse of escorting a child to the film.

reviews.review_title: Make that 5 for 5 for Pixar in 8 years!
reviews.content: Outstanding! Disney and Pixar are a perfect match now for the 5th time straight!!This movie has everything. The best digital animations to date, the story is classic yet intropective with a grand parental charm and wit coupled with brave and ingenious relationships, genuine heart-felt characters and a clean sweeping pace to the story.It was a tremendous 2 hours of movie magic at its very best. I highly recommend this film. I can't wait for the dvd we will buy it and cherish it for years just as we do with Bugs life, the Toys Story's and Monsters Inc. have entertained us as well. This is a new level though, the water surface is incredible and real looking. New fresh look and feel for Pixar and Disney. My three year old and my 11 year old as my wife and I loved this film!!!This is by far the best yet from Pixar/Disney. Thanks for raising the bar guys! A definate 10 out of 10!!!-can I see it again, -please?!

Ellen Degeneres is FANTASTIC as the voice of Dory in this movie, she totally makes the movie.  Her character keeps you laughing from beginning to end, even during the parts where you feel like crying!  She has a lot of talent, and the role was perfect for her sense of humor.  The rest of that case also does an excellent job, I felt as if Disney made a quality effort to make this just as enjoyable for adults as for children, except for the poor little boy that sat behind me in the theater, "It's too scary Mommy, I wanna go home!"  All of the other children really seemed to be having a good time.

So pretty and so funny.  This is great entertainment with dazzling visuals and a really funny script.  I rarely laugh out loud but I did in this movie. The reefs and sea life sometimes looks so real and other times better than real.  Never mind the kids, I want to see it again!

Not having small children, I have had no great desire to see this highly touted work.  My wife rented it, and I was willing...  Yes, it was interesting to watch from a technical standpoint, but there was little else to hold my attention.  Besides the animation, Ellen DeGeneres' work was the only real redeeming quality - she was wonderful.  It is surely for kids and their parents.

I like it because it is Australian mate. I like the seagulls because they go like MOIT MOIT. My mum likes the pelican because he smashes into the window all the time. I like Eric Bana in it and the other guy. My mums favourite characters in it are probably Dory, the pelican, Nemo and the fish that's like BUBBLES! BUBBLES! It has a really good storyline. It is insanely funny, well maybe not insanely funny like very funny. My brother also really likes it. He likes the seagulls like me. Finally my dad thinks it is pretty good. I think dory is pretty funny as well. It is funny when she runs into marlin, Nemo's dad.

The undersea adventure that Pixar presents is undoubtedly more fleshed out than Disney's "Little Mermaid". The characters are 'human', not just the bland sidekicks found in Disney movies, and the society of "Fish Predators Anonymous" was hilarious. Willem Dafoe is brilliant as the morose Gill.I appreciate the factual detail in the movie. It is set in the Great Barrier Reef - *it* is the largest structure in the world built by living creatures, not New York -  the East Australian Current does lead to New South Wales, clown fish are abundant near the Reef, and there are toxic jellyfish off the Northern coast of Australia. It was nice to listen to the marine life speaking with aussie accents.But for the fifth time running, a Pixar movie is about a journey of rescue. The formula seems to be wearing out. There are obvious comparisons to be made with Miyazaki, who manages to come up with highly original themes each time a movie is made, making each of them a success. Why do Disney and Pixar not follow the lead? [And, how is a fart joke, good humour?]

"Nemo" had a great advertising just like other films (Shrek, The Incredibles, Chicken Little), and their grand success can be partially explained that way. "Nemo" was promoted like another rebirth of Disney and the greatest picture Pixar has never made. The graphics were outstanding, although I was never keen of seeing more than one time 3D animated movies. The original concept, although not very original, was good for standing away from the silly-piggish-not-that-funny-dull-stupid script that 3D animated computer features had taken (aka Shrek, Shark Tale, Madagascar, Shrek II and III, and just because they enjoy to milk the cow, maybe IV, V, VI...). "Nemo" stands aside from this. But are some negative aspects. While watching this movie on cinema, some little kids fell asleep during the second part and most of them claimed that the film was just too long and the adults complained about the slow story pace. I can say the same. The thing with Nemo's mother death was so unoriginal, that they even called this "Bambi and The Lion King deep in the sea" The parts with Nemo trapped in the dentist office were boring and with its develop, even Marlin and Dory plot with their "platonic love" was going the same way. A good soundtrack could easily distract the audience but there was no good soundtrack and not even bad. There was none. Some Disney films needed some time but this should be cut at half.

reviews.review_title: Two thumbs way, way up! Pixar shines again!
reviews.content: I confess, I wasn't sure about Finding Nemo from the trailers. I was a little worried that this was a classic case of all the laugh lines being packed into a 2 minute version of the film.Let me reassure you, it's not the case. The film is very funny - a laugh a minute - and over way, way too soon. The visuals are beautiful, the undersea depiction is for the most part true-to-life, the story is good, and the message is worthwhile.In short, I loved it. Keep 'em coming, Pixar, while you've still got the magic in you!

reviews.review_title: Following in the footsteps of Shrek, NEMO exceeds in humor
reviews.content: Well, I can honestly say... I'm 23 and a guy, yet for one reason or another I find myself put in these situations to watch Children's movies. I've seen Shrek, which I loved. Now, I've seen Finding Nemo, which I love MORE. Ellen Degeneres had me, as well as other adults there with their children, cracking up throughout the movie and I'm not afraid to admit it. While I hate Albert Brooks with a passion, he was perfect for the role of Nemo's father (voice wise). He, however, was the only character I hated. But I loved all the Tank Fish, and Dory, and the Sharks, & others were all wonderful. I think any open minded person who can enjoy a laugh, or who can remember their youth, would enjoy this movie. For Children it is a fun cartoon full of adventure and surprise. For Adults it is a great movie that makes you reflect on your youth, and if you are a parent, yourself as a parent. It also gives you laughs you'd never expect to have in a movie like this. While Shrek was meaningful and romantic, Finding Nemo was hilarious and really got you into it and has another message to get to everyone and I HIGHLY Recommend you see this before it leaves theatres, and if it's too late.. Go out and get it on DVD ASAP, for yourself OR your Children.

Pixar has done an outstanding job on this one. For the last few years I have found out that every time I go to see an animated movie, it seems more realistic. The computer graphics are extremely fine tuned to match the character's personality and voice. The movie is inspiring on various levels. Firstly, the strong bonding between a father and son is depicted with exceptional clarity. The first school-going experience is so close to human experience that kids can immediately relate to it. It makes one wish , every kid had a affectionate and daring father like Marlin. For those kids (or adults) who have'nt known a father's love, the father-son scenes could be quite emotional. Secondly, the general underlying message of preserving marine life in its pristine form is well conveyed. The current commercial fishing practice of trawling the ocean floor clean with utter disregard to any life is shocking to say the least. I hope people and governments take notice and do something to prevent the destruction of the last frontier on this planet. Overall the movie is thoroughly enjoyable whether you are kid or an adult.

reviews.review_title: Up there with The Nightmare Before Christmas and Toy Story.
reviews.content: When I originally saw the poster for this film (big empty space with a single fish), I instantly wanted to watch it, as I thought it was just beautiful. However, then I saw the trailers, and thought it just looked like a typical cutesy disney kids film.Today I watched it on VHS, and realised that my original ideas of what it would be like were indeed accurate. Within five minutes of the film starting, we given one of the most emotive scenes I've ever seen in a children's film, and it actually makes you feel stupid for getting so worked up over a film which is meant for children!The story is predictable, which is understandable as I doubt Pixar wanted to bewilder the children. However, this is made up for as the character development is great, as we see the isolated culture of the fish tank, and the class system between the different sea creatures (crabs being simple tramps, turtles being richer 'californian' thrillseekers etc.)The way the film has been made is also great, with the amazing endless underwater landscapes, and the brilliant musical score from Thomas Newman (American Beauty, Six Feet Under). The film has the poetry of Tim Burton's The Nightmare Before Christmas, with the tongue-in-cheek humour of Toy Story, and the emotion of Watership Down, making it one of the best children's films I have ever been fortunate enough to see.

reviews.review_title: A fantastic movie, about a little fish called Nemo who is swept into adventures above and under the sea!
reviews.content: A fantastic movie, about a little fish called Nemo who is swept into adventures above and under the sea! Nemo is the only remaining fish after his brothers, sisters, and mother have a dreadful experience with a shark. His father becomes overprotective of Nemo especially after Nemo is taken by a scubadiver and placed in a fish tank at a dentist's office. While wildly searching for Nemo, his father meets a comedic fish who suffers from short term memory loss. The two have adventures under the sea and meet an oceanful of fun!

reviews.review_title: Amazing Animation, Colorful Characters, Terrific Tale!
reviews.content: I have always been a Big fan of animated films, ex. Alladin, Beauty and The Beast, Toy Story, etc.  Yet, I have felt of late the animated pictures have been lacking the depth in story and the beauty in animation that they once held.  Finding Nemo has truly, in my opinion, found those elements again. I was greatly entertained with the films intriguing characters and profound plot.  True it is just a cartoon but it was better than your average cartoon:  It relayed the message of letting go. Many people know from experience what it is like to loose a loved one and how that loss effects how a person lives his or her life.  Finding Nemo relayed this concept in a very gentle and truthful way.  A+ Well done Pixar and Disney.  Thanks for going back to the good Days.

reviews.review_title: Not up to Pixar's usual standard?
reviews.content: I finally got around to seeing this on DVD. I was looking forward to it, but I was rather disappointed - compared to Pixar's other work. I don't know how it could be rated higher than either of the Toy story's.Sure it's technically fantastic, and there are some good moments (Bruce the Shark for example) - but it left me cold. For me there are couple of reasons. I would say it's the most "Disney like" of all the Pixar films so far (and for me that's a bad thing!) - all rather preachy and predicable. Although at least there was no bursting into song!I think it could have done with some trims at the editing stage - the film is 20+ mins longer than Toy Story, and you notice it. The Turtle & Jellyfish scenes dragged on, and seemed unnecessary to me.Let's hope The Incredibles is a return to form for 'older' viewers.

I think that this film was beautifully done. The voice talents were perfect for their characters. I think that Helen DeGeneres deserves special mention for her zany character. I'd like to know how much of what she said she made up and how much was scripted. If it was all scripted, she's a genius because her lines sound absolutely spontaneous. The animation was poignant and extremely accurate. It shows that these guys did their marine life homework before making this film. The story is (as most are) an old one of growing up and letting go but I am particularly grateful to the writers for not putting too many fight/nagging scenes as most movies/TV programs do when they use this type of plot. Why they decided for the story to take place in Australia I have no idea but hey, why not? This is truly a universally appealing movie that would be good for anyone to see.

The best so far to come out of Pixar-Disney. True to form, the computer-digital effects are fantastic.
Ellen Degeneres is the most talented of the voices we hear in this delightful underwater tale.  Her performance allows for her blue tane character, Dory, to come alive in so many beautiful and hilariously entertaining ways."Finding Nemo" features numerous sea mines, possessively-hungry seagulls ("Mine, Mine, Mine!") and aquatic acquaintances that reinforce the importance of friendship.The plot is a rehash of other more familiar Disney films.  You won't have trouble listing them.  And you won't have to bring the kids with you to watch it.  Most of the audience I saw this film with were well over 18yrs of age.  Slightly irritating is the fact that the narrative continuously bounces back and forth between the two separated clown fish (Marlin and his son Nemo), and the film appears to run 15 minutes too long for my otherwise liberal attention span.

reviews.review_title: Cruelest beginning for a kids' movie . . .
reviews.content: Okay, if you don't want to know anything about the beginning of the movie, stop reading. *** Our movie begins with idyllic life on the reef. We find two clownfish, Marlin (Albert Brooks) and Coral (Elizabeth Perkins) enjoying their new home (a sea anemone). He's concerned it's not big enough, she says it will be just fine, and they check on their 500 children, which are quivering fish fetuses in translucent fish eggs. Ah, how nice, how cute! Suddenly though, out of nowhere, a barracuda shows up and attacks the home. Marlin does the best he can, telling Coral to hide inside the anemone; however, Coral's concerned about the "kids" and goes to save them. The barracuda then swats Marlin unconscious into the protective tendrils of his home, and everything fades to black. When Marlin comes to, Coral has disappeared (we assume she's become dinner) and every single one of the eggs has been either destroyed or eaten except for one -- Nemo.Of course, as if killing Marlin's wife and kids off wasn't cruel enough, Nemo suffers from a birth defect, which results in him having a "gimp fin." Dad refers to it as Nemo's lucky fin, but at this point, I'm just thinking that there's nothing lucky about this family of fish.From here on, the movie takes on a decidedly lighter tone, but it's not long before Nemo's snapped up by some skin divers and taken away to a new home in a dentist's aquarium. This is where the real plot of the film begins.The film is a journey film, and as such, it merely acts as a pretense for a wide variety of loosely related sketches. At times, the sequences seem like they could function on their own as stand-alone shorts. If you don't like a sequence, skip it on the DVD player -- you won't have missed much -- you can just assume that Marlin and Dory (his forgetful companion in the movie)have yet escaped another life-threatening and/or humorous random encounter and are now back on track, searching for Nemo.Also, like many other Pixar films, there's a lot of satirization of the ordinary, work-a-day world around us. Nemo's aquarium home becomes a metaphor for densely-packed urban areas filled with cubical-dwellers. Also, a "Flock of Seagulls" serves as an amusing reminder of the idiocy of blind greed and mob mentality.Still, the movie's a bit overlong with a few too many cliffhangers at the end. Just when it seemed the movie should have been wrapping up, there was ONE MORE crazy, death-defying action sequence tacked on to tie up a loose end that I didn't really care about. The Incredibles had a similar false-ending/new crisis ending, but that movie's "new crisis" was entertaining rather than mundane. By the near end of Nemo, I was simply thinking, "Let's get back to the reef!" The animation was wonderful, but overall, the story seemed labored, disconnected, and imperfect. Dory provided some great laughs but also got on my nerves. There were parts I loved (seagulls, Sharks Anonymous, the Aquarium, turtles, Dory) but there were parts that either bored or annoyed me (the whale, the jellyfish, the net, the deep sea creature, and Dory). A mixed bag to be sure.

Rarely have I actually laughed out loud in a movie theater 6 times. Probably the best comedy since, Monty Python and the Holy Grail.  The jokes were good for both adults and kids.  The second best thing may be that the plot was not just a pretense it actually was nice.

reviews.review_title: Awe-inspiring animation does not a watchable movie make
reviews.content: First things first.  Ellen Degeneres and Albert Brooks aren't funny. They never have been.  So when Disney slots this bungling pair as the voices of the two lead characters in FINDING NEMO, then we haven't got much to look forward to.  Or have we?  After all, the animation is stunning.  And once we get past the fact that Degeneres' voice comes from a fish actually modeled to look like her, then it is momentarily possible to get lost in the pixelated splendor of Disney's greatest animating achievement to date. The sea sparkles with the magical touches of what must have been countless talented, tireless animators.  But is this enough?  The plot stinks like a rancid Freudian family drama.   And the missing sexual tension between the two lead characters (both single) is a glaring mistake.  But it does have something going for it.  Almost every scene on land is fantastic.  The comedy is spot on, and the noticeable disparity between good jokes and great timing (on land) and dull, tiresome jokes in the sea (where most of the movie is spent, and where Brooks and Degeneres flounder along, oblivious to their own inanity) make the humor on land seem that much better. Overall, however, the movie is unbearable.  It's one thing for it to be unswervingly predictable.  Sure, every Disney movie is.  But getting from beginning to end doesn't have to seem like a chore, a penance for some wrong that i didn't realize i committed.  Or maybe the wrong was simply buying the movie tickets and supporting Disney.  And i sure got punished for that.

After seeing a brief trailer for this on the Monsters Inc dvd,I couldnt wait to see this movie.But I was shocked to find out we wouldnt be getting a release in the UK until October.Luckily for me I had a trip to New York planned so I made sure a visit to the movies was planned.All I could say is wow,it lives up to Pixars high standards and it got a big thumbs up from my eight year old son.Everything from the characters to the animation is nothing short of spectacular,I will certainly be paying another visit to the movies again in October when it is released here.It is just a shame they couldnt have released it here for the summer.But as the saying goes all good things come to those who wait.UNMISSABLE***** out of *****

Well my favorite Disney film still is Lilo & Stitch but this one is truly going second!I know I know most of you won't agree with me but I'm a Disney lover of the new generation and the old. And movies like Atlantis the lost Empire, Treasure Planet and especially Lilo & Stitch entertain me just as well as Alladin and the Lion King did for me while I was little!Finding Nemo is truly great on itself and profits from truly beatifull animation work! The story is adorable and the characters are perfect for young and old! I liked Dory the little female fishy suffering from a short-term memory loss. D0h I also liked Memento would it be because of that?Well not much to say further, excellent animation, voice acting and a perfect story about a dad who has to look for his sun in the ocean(it's much better as it sounds.)Disney (Pixar actually) still rules and as long as they keep up the good work I will be watching this movies till I am dead!**** out of Five!

I liked everything about this film. To me it has the important message that a parent would do anything for their child,which is important considering there's so much turmoil going on in the world today. Finding Nemo is a very entertaining film for all ages......looks like Disney and Pixtar did it once again!

i thought it was quite cool i would watch it again...it was funny and kept you interested...there was complety no boring moments...my fave character had to be the blue fish...it was funny...cant wait to get it on dvd!

I thought this was precious. Even if you're not a kid you'll still love it. In every Disney movie I've ever seen there are always jokes that kids will never get but the adults always pick up on. Nemo is no different. And the characters are so funny. There's this one character named Bubbles, he lives in a fish tank and every time this little treasure chest opens it let's out little bubbles. And every time they come out he races over to it screaming "Bubbles! Bubbles! My bubbles!" He's just so funny. And the sea turtles are awesome! Totally. =], anyhow, it's really such a wonderful movie, and you really feel for the characters. All Nemo is trying to do it get home to his daddy. Its so sad, but he's got great friends to help him out! Very cute, A+!

Finding Nemo is a very funny movie!I absolutely loved it.The story follows a father who is overprotective of his son.On the first day of school, Marlin(father) believes that his son,Nemo, is not yet ready for school ,but Nemo thinks otherwise and swims in to open sea and gets fishnapped and Marlin goes in search of him.On the way, he meets a fish with short-term memory loss named Dory and she helps him look for his son.They also meet a couple of sharks and some totally far out sea turtles.Meanwhile,Nemo is welcomed to a club with a bunch of fish he meets in a tank in a dentists office.And I'll leave the rest for you to watch.Kids and adults of all ages will most definitely love it.Overall 10/10 stars.

reviews.review_title: Pixar has done a good job..
reviews.content: Finding nemo is not the best film that Disney has ever created, however it can be said that it's very good. I've watched 3 times.. The events in the movie are easily estimated while we are watching. There is not so much surprises but the humor and the characters are fantastic. The kid turtles and vegetarian sharks are very nice.. The story is around a little crown fish which is kidnapped by the people who are living in Sydney.. His father wants to find him and there are humorous events while searching.. The colors are so vivid and the atmosphere of the ocean is very well designated.. I recommend the film but not strongly, It's nice but not perfect.. It can attract the children and it's a family name."Mutlu Bahar"

Pixar  has created a  visually stunning animated movie. I could spend all day staring at this great animated aquarium that "Nemo" has delivered. Nemo with its great animation is worth seeing!  but only seeing.  the fact than many people are calling this a classic  makes me wonder what movie they saw.  What makes a classic animated movie  is  a good story  and strong characters.  I believe Nemo fails on both counts.  The story line is a basic one.  We follow the path of two fish, nemo and his father marlin  as they get seperated and their attempt to reunite.   The scenes depicted are nicely done  but you feel like you are being swept from one scene to another, the segways are missing. The story line is not deep enough so you can walk away feeling that you missed something in the storyline,  which in fact you haven't, there just isn't anything else there.   The film is also missing out on strong characters. The main characters would all be considered good supporting charcters,  but unfortunately  are asked to carry the  movie. But in their defense how much character can a fish have?  The point being is that finding nemo is a  beautifully animated film about fish  delivering a bunch of comedic lines  telling a simple story  that makes you want more than it delivers.   To me a classic delivers more than you want.

I really can't describe my distaste for a children's movie in which you have to skip the entire first scene so as not to give the children nightmares. It really wasn't necessary to SHOW how Nemo and his father came to be alone. The animation is superb, but I expected, after all the build-up I'd read and heard, to hear a lot more laughter from the children watching it. This flick can't hold a candle to "Monsters, Inc."

This movie was full of great characters but I was disappointed that it was one non-stop stressful scene after another.  My four year old was traumatized.   You couldn't even sit back and enjoy the fantastic comedy because the main characters were on the verge of death in practically every scene.   What's with all the murdered/dead parent themes in Disney movies anyway?  Monsters Inc. and Bug's Life both had much better balances of funny scenes and exciting/scary scenes.

"Finding Nemo," is an excellent movie for viewers of all ages. In this movie, three valuable life lessons are shared: 1) parents protect their children because they love and care for them, 2) teamwork is important in being successful, and 3) your differences do not define you. These lessons can apply to viewers of all ages and are presented throughout the course of the movie. Overall, "Finding Nemo" was nearly flawless. From the outstanding animation, to the talented voices of actors/actresses, to the entertaining jokes and plot, I find this to be one of Disney Pixar's best movies.

This is one of the best movies I've seen in such a long time. I laughed,my 15 year old laughed, my 12 year old laughed, and my 8 year old laughed!We were still laughing when we got home. There was nothing rude in it. It was good clean fun!A MUST see!!!

I love the Toy Story movies and enjoyed Monsters Inc., so I was looking forward to Finding Nemo. Unfortunately, Nemo was not nearly as enjoyable as Pixar's other fine movies.I found very few genuine laughs in Nemo. I thought Dory, a fish with short term memory, was cute and had a few funny moments, but otherwise the movie fell flat. A lot of the jokes were just not funny. Some of the characters were your typical run of the mill cartoon characters, such as the 'surfer-dude' turtle, which I could have done without.Technically, Nemo looks great. The visuals are good. But, I can't help thinking with the whole underwater world that they could not come up with more dazzling characters other than shark, turtle, whale, etc...
The bottom line is that Nemo is a pretty movie that ends up feeling empty with very few laughs and flat characters. I give it a 5 out of 10.

what a great film. i went to see it with my two girls and we had the best of times. Scary, interesting, full of adventure, intelligent, hopeful, and everything i didn't mention. I loved it and my kids loved it!! Every once in a while Hollywood does produce a good think, especially for kids. When I was young it was snowithe. I remember how great that film was and I felt my girls were having the same experience as i did 30 years earlier. I wish Hollywood wasn't so much about stupidity; rather produce something that is good for the whole humanity and for the kids. I'd give it a 10 just because it has an educational value to it!

reviews.review_title: The sea monkey took my money! (You have to see the movie.)
reviews.content: I'm not a parent or an artist, so I can't comment on how kid-friendly this movie is or anything about the technical aspects. I can say, however, as a relatively intelligent 35-year old, I loved this movie. I laughed harder (mostly at Ellen DeGenerges' character Dori) than I've laughed in a movie in a long time. (Even the short before the feature presenation was really funny.) I never really had any doubt how the movie would end, but still enjoyed how it got there. Albert Brooks and Allison Janney were also standouts. The sharks "in recovery" were great too.Tip - - Stay for the little bonus scene within the first couple of minutes of the end credits.

What can I say about this movie? One word - Brilliant. Pixar have had a long track record of having yet to make anything less than a very good film but even though its almost unanimously agreed that all of them have been great, it seems everyone still has their preferences. To give you an idea of my taste I just adore "A Bug's Life" which I think is pretty much a pitch perfect movie with great characters and story. I enjoyed "Toy Story" but wasn't a huge fan of it, the sequel however is an absolute classic hands down. After 'Bugs' and 'TS2' though came "Monsters Inc" which again was a really good movie but I wasn't a huge fan of as the "Where the Wild Things Are"-cloned concept was fine but like TS1 the film got too juvenile and sentimentally sweet for me with the humor just worth the odd giggle more than anything else and only the awesome 'doors' sequence standing out in my mind.'Nemo' however has now taken the crown - its at least equal best with TS2 and the more I think about it the more its rising to be stand out Number One. EVERYTHING about this movie is practically flawless - the animation, the characters, the story, the emotional resonance, the humor, etc. is incredible. Its a film you can't help but get swept up in right from the get-go, in fact I can't remember a film where I really ran the gamut of emotions from happy and awed to despair and terror - and this film manages to do all that in just the opening five-minute sequence. Its a 100 minute underwater road movie but never ever gets slow or tired and even some Disney-style father-son sentimentality bits oddly enough generate genuine heart and warmth.*Ellen DeGeneres deserved an Osar nomination for her flawless performance as Dory.

reviews.review_title: The Best Piece of Disney and Pixar
reviews.content: I LOVED THIS MOVIE! You like coke? This movie will make you love water!! The friendly (or not) expressions from the characters, the funny and perfectly matched voices, the story, the idea, and everything is awesome! The soundtrack is what I like the most, maybe. Thomas Newman is for me an inspiration and my distractor (for good) on every occasion! The Ending song makes me wanna cry... And every moment of this movie is preceded by his music, which creates a natural, exotic, and beautiful climate.About the animation, is Pixar my friends! It's perfect!I highly recommend this movie. One of my favorites (I saw the latinoamerican Spanish and English version, i liked both a lot!). It's the perfect movie for every occasion, for adults, kids, and teenagers too!5/5 *****

The latest in a string of tightly written and superbly animated features from Pixar Studios, who have risen to become gods of animation. Finding Nemo begins with one of the darkest openings in Disney cartoon history, telling the story of a father clown-fish named Merlin who loses his wife and all but one of his hundreds of fish eggs in a tragedy destined to make you think twice about ordering fish and chips for dinner. Marlin becomes the over-protective father of Nemo, his sole surviving child who is kidnapped by a scuba diving dentist and placed in a fish tank in his operating room. Thus the search begins, and Marlin must travel through the Great Barrier Reef to rescue his son, conquering his fears and meeting all sorts of strange and interesting creatures on the way (Bruce, a shark battling a ravishing fish addiction, is particularly memorable) The story thrives on simplicity, riding a singular concept all the way to a gloriously satisfying conclusion, and the script is choc-a-block full of gags and one-liners that are genuinely funny for all ages. This, in fact, is the perfect family movie: gorgeous to look at, tightly wound and high-octane, without a trace of pretension or dumb-downed ideals that so frequently condescend the younger market. Finding Nemo is one of the best animated films ever made, a glorious awe-inspiring tale comparable to classics like The Lion King.

I enjoyed this movie very much. I selected it for a movie review in high school and watched it more than 5 times in a row. The ultimate mix, sadness and joy, as usual in Disney movies was certenly included this time.

I never thought I would rave about a movie about fish. Actually, this story is about much more than that. It is about family and love and a tender relationship between a father and a son. I am not going to lie. At the end of this movie, I really teared up and almost cried. This movie was very heartfelt and it's definitely, without a doubt, the funniest movie I have seen this year.The casting in this movie was sheer perfection. Brooks and Gould do great as the father and son, but the standout of the movie, is of course, Dory, voiced by the great Ellen DeGeneres. This is the best voice-over work since Robin Williams in Aladdin. A truly stellar voice over job with so many LOL moments. Also great was the 'tank gang,' as I like to call them. Great voice-over works from Garrett, Dafoe, and Janney.The script for this movie is so fresh and so amazing that it crosses age barriers. It is a simple story that goes very far.Two 50 year-old, a 19 year-old, and a year-old all laughed equally during this movie. It truly is a movie for all ages. A funny and heart-tugging story for everyone.Nothing more to say that hasn't already. This is one GREAT movie.

Finding Nemo contains a message slightly more complex than usually associated with family films, but as written and co-directed by Andrew Stanton, it's eloquently presented in a context that carries it through with potency. Stanton doesn't shy away from trauma -- the film contains its share, including an opening tragedy that rivals the shooting of Bambi's mother, but also pays respect to the precarious and predatory nature of undersea life. Everything is part of the food chain in the nautical world. It's the best circle of life message since Disney's The Lion King.The film is awash in humor -- the sharks, for instance, are fearsome in their toothy glory. But these guys are also going through a 12-Step program -- "Fish are friends, not food " -- adding a wacky hilarity (when one of them goes for Marlin, the other two rush to block, crying out "Intervention! "). One of the movie's funniest bits is also one of its most dazzling, as Marlin and Dory encounter a school of fish who, as a collective, are adept at impersonations. Finding Nemo keeps the excitement quotient on high -- sometimes a little too high, as the action gets to be dizzying in spots. And the narrative transitions between the ocean and the dentist's office are structurally awkward.The film possesses a luster and beauty never before seen in an animated film, computer or otherwise. The refraction of light, the gentle, cresting wave of sea anemones, the constant flutter of fish, sets up a background environment that is constantly in motion. The computing power alone needed to render this kind of realism is staggering. Finding Nemo lures you into its world, to the point where you feel almost as though you are floating under the sea. It's a remarkable achievement, a perfect pairing of genuine artistry with technology.Stanton and co-director Lee Unkrich coax stunning vocal performances out of an A-List cast. Albert Brooks, one of my own personal favorites, gives an anything-but-floundering performance as Marlin, the consummate neurotic-yet-loving parent. But it's DeGeneres who steals every frame of film as Dory, who, in an inspired touch, has no short-term memory. And you will not soon forget the brilliantly funny sequence in which Dory attempts to communicate with a whale. DeGeneres transcends the character's surface humor and winds up providing the film's most poignant, heartfelt performance. If there were an Oscar for best portrayal of a tropical fish, our Ellen would win by more than a fin.

I'm always consistently amazed at what Pixar is able to do. With each passing film, they improve their craft again and again, transporting us to worlds where toys talk, insects can make inventions, and where monsters live and work just like we do. With their latest release, "Finding Nemo," I am reminded once again why I love going to the movies.The environment of the film is painfully detailed and realistic. My favorite example occurs in the salt-water fish tank that Nemo is being held in. In order to escape, the fish have to sabotage the tank. When they do sabotage it, the tank begins to get dirty instantly. If you've ever had a salt-water tank, you know that as soon as the little bubble thing stops working, the grim begins to gather and start forming in the tank almost instantly. It's such a great touch.Two of my favorite scenes involved the jellyfish forest and the inside of the whale. Marlin and Dory have to race through a jellyfish forest. All around are these pink orbs with tentacles and the animation is sharp and quick. It is a heart racing sequence that I honestly feel had the same excitement level of the car chase scene in "The Matrix Reloaded." The whale scene is just beautifully detailed, particularly on the whale's tongue. I honestly thought it was a real tongue.Speaking of real, Pixar has the incredible ability to cause you to forget that toys, insects, monsters, and now fish aren't actually human. They talk just like humans do ("What is with men and asking for directions?"). A standout scene occurs when Marlin has given up and saving Nemo and is ready to abandon Dory and go back to the reef. Dory gives an impassioned, demonstrative plea to not give up and keep her on as a friend, something that she sees Marlin desperately needs. The scene does not at all feel out place in this tightly paced film.The reason this film works is because these fish seem human and because the fish display their voice's owners great. Even if you've just seen the previews for "The In-Laws," you can see that Albert Brooks has experience playing the nervous, frantic, neurotic worrywart. Marlin's facial expressions even resemble a few of Brooks'. Dafoe's Gill is edgy, but has a hint of quiet desperation lined with hope of getting back to his home waters and out of that awful tank. But the real scene stealer is DeGeneres as Dory. Scatterbrained, peppy, light-hearted, and caring with an obvious intelligence, Dory is simply the core of the film. DeGeneres deserves an Oscar nomination for such a fine performance.

First off: the animation work is excellent. From a technical perspective this is a fine movie. It also has a few truly funny moments (sharks) and fairly decent voice-acting..But this movie is terribly reminiscent of half the sitcoms and children's movies out there. It is like a cross-section of California stereotypes were given plastic surgery and dropped in water. The formula has been been tortured to death by Hollywood in general and Disney in particular.Thus, Finding Nemo makes good watching for young children and people who don't see many films, but movie-lovers will find it boring and stale.On the whole not a bad movie, but hardly an original piece of work: 3/5..

Yeah Pixar! Rock it! You're 5 for 5 and have never made a bad movie. Not many people can say that... enjoy it! Stick it to Disney when you get your chance! Excellent voice work all around.. Albert Brooks may have been a little wasted but Ellen more than made up for it. Oh and I'm sick of all the whining about her being cast in the movie. She's a comedian. She's paid to be funny. She is funny. Nemo is a funnier movie because of her. Quit it! Let the woman do her job. Should Disneyworld start refusing to hire gay people? Come on!"I am ashamed..."

reviews.review_title: Pixar took me me a swim
reviews.content: First and foremost, this is the most unbelievably and wickedly real! I just can't believe Pixar has successfully made me feel I'm 'in' the oceans with the rest of the millions and billions of fishes! The animations were flawlessly realistic. Everything shown was superb! I will most definitely recommend this movie to friends/people! trust me, it's worthwhile!

reviews.review_title: Will be regarded as a modern day classic
reviews.content: Isn't it great that in these times of war, terror and fear that there is a company like PIXAR, who can produce wonderful, entertaining and intelligent movies. Finding Nemo is their best work yet, but I say that after each of their movies( Toy Stories 1 & II, Monsters INC etc). To achieve such magical effects is a wonderous feat, but to combine this with a magnificent script and to have such brilliant character actors such as Albert Brooks, Ellen Degeneres, and Geoffrey Rush, to name a few, justs tops it off for me. Remember the Wizard of Oz?..... I believe that in many Years to come, when we are long gone.... Finding Nemo will be referred to in the same way... a magical movie classic!

A remarkable movie. One of the best animated movie of all time. It has great characters, a load of funny dialogue, and artistic images that only Pixar can create. It's a story of an overprotective father, doing his duty as a single parent for his only son, Nemo. The father, named Marlin, went panic when Nemo got caught by some divers. So, began the journey of finding his son, Nemo (who's now in the aquarium with other fish). Marlin met a forgotful fish named Dory who helped him in finding his son. On the other hand, Nemo and the aquarium gank desperately wanted to get out from the aquarium. This story is full of message, that parents should be more trustful to their children. That teamwork can solve your problems. That, even if you're a handicapped person, doesn't mean that you can't do anything.  Doesn't mean that you have to be protected. It's a family entertainment with heavy message. It's an animated feature at it's most amazing graphics. You'll actually feel wet while watching this movie. It's like you are one of the fish in the computer generated ocean.Finding Nemo takes animation technique further than what Toy Story did. You just have to see it to believe it. What I love the most about this movie is the richness of it's characters. You'll immediately love Marlin, Dory, Nemo and other characters in this picture. Because they are so real. So funny. So memorable. Finding Nemo has a big strenght in comedy too. Just hear the dialogue and get ready to laugh out loud. There's plenty of jokes here. The clownfish who isn't funny. Sharks who don't eat fish. A pelican who befriend with fish. Sea turtles who talks like surfers. As Pixar said, you just gotta sea it. Sea it. It's better than any of the recent Disney films. It's a treasure, and shares a room with Beauty and The Beast, Lion King, Aladdin and others as the best family entertainment of all time. See it, you won't be disappointed, you'll love it, you'll thank me for that, and you'll know that I'm not lying. 9/10

It seems as though rated "G" movies are often under-advertised and never really make money or are even worth watching. Generally they're made specifically for children and any humor in the movie is lost on those over the age of seven. Pixar, in the past, has defied these common sentiments with movies like Toy Story 1, Toy Story 2, A Bug's Life, and Monster's Inc. Pixar continues to defy standard Hollywood practices with the release of Finding Nemo.This movie is, by at least a little bit, the best rated G movie I've ever seen. Monster's Inc comes in a little behind in second place. The animation in this movie is incredible, the water, the fish, the particles of dirt floating in the water...there were many points when I would watch the movie and could definitely not be sure whether I was looking at a real or animated sea-scape.The story...the story wasn't anything particularly groundbreaking other than the setting...father loses his son, will do anything to find him. In this case, anything includes taking on sharks, jellyfish, pelicans and other random sea monsters. The father, Marlin, is a clownfish that defies his name by being particularly unfunny...luckily he picks up a sidekick early on with a short term memory problem - a little memento-esque.Nemo, the son, is captured by divers and put in an aquarium in Australia, where he meets several psychotic fish including "Gills," another fish from the open sea - whose voice belongs to William Dafoe (in a non-bad guy role!).Of course, being a comedy, the movie does have a happy ending, but the ending isn't nearly as much fun as the trip taken to get there. The movie is great, I went along with two college age friends, and they both laughed as much as I did. If a kid's movie can make three college students laugh as hard as we did...it is definitely worthwhile seeing. The movie is genuinely funny and worth watching with the entire family. The movie is safe for small children, though there are a couple of potentially scary scenes that might frighten *really* young children. However, I would definitely recommend going to a later showing...after most children would be in bed. I made the mistake of watching "Ice Age" at 5 PM - and the theater was unfortunately filled the the laughter/screams/crying of children, which took a little away from the movie for me.One more thing - Pixar shares a short 3-5 minute computer animated short. In fact, it was the first short ever created by Pixar. The short was also very humorous and just made the whole movie experience more enjoyable. There was also a preview for Pixar's upcoming movie: "The Incredibles" which seems to be about a dysfunctional family of aging superheroes which I can only assume will be just as enjoyable and amusing as "Nemo."

reviews.review_title: Grab Shell for the ride of your life!
reviews.content: If you haven't seen this movie get down to the cinema before you miss out on the best film of all time! It is without a doubt the sweetest, funniest, most exciting film I (and many others) have seen in years! The backgrounds are beautiful and so life-like! And I can barely find words to describe the characters. They are superbly animated and are brought to life by some extremly talented actors. If (and I very much doubt it) you aren't sure of the plot, here's an insight to it: After the death of his wife and 399 children, Marlin the Clownfish becomes over-protective of his only surviving son, Nemo. When Nemo gets tired of his fathers protectiveness, he abandons the safety of his home and ends up being captured by an Austrailian diver. Nemo then finds himself in the company of the 'Tank Gang' in a dentists office tank. Meanwhile, Marlin desperatly tries to find his son, with the help of the memory-losing, optimistic and Danger-Prone Dory, a Regal Blue Tang fish. Together they encouter vegitarian sharks, a forest of Jellyfish, the EAC-surfing turtles and many more colourful characters in this story about the seas most dedicated father, Marlin and the funniest fish in the world, Dory. I am positive that any Disney-Pixar, fish or touching-movie fan will not be able to resist the brilliance of this film. Treat yourself to Disney-Pixars Greatest acheivement, Finding Nemo! 10/10! Jenny xxx

This has to be one of the best animated movies ever!  It was funny, exiting, well animated, and suitable for all age groups (well, really young ones might find it a bit scary).  The animation was unbelievable - there were scenes that could have been straight out of a photograph, if things weren't moving in it.  Of course, the characters don't look that realistic, but they are still very well animated, I was impressed as usual by Pixar's talent. I thought the acting was great, the characters were very well done, and the dentist scenes were just funny beyond belief.  And the sea turtles.  I usually don't like Disney movies, but this one takes the cake.

reviews.review_title: So cute, and so much fun!
reviews.content: What a cute movie! I saw the previews for it and I was excited, but I wondered how many other people in their early 20's would be excited to see a little fish movie. But tonight the theater was packed with people of all ages. I laughed so hard and was very entertained. The voices were great [Ellen DeGeneres was awesome!] and the special effects were very impressive. I can't wait to buy the DVD! :) A definite must-see: 10/10.

it was ok to me.it was worth going to see but i think that only little kids and adults will enjoy this movie.I am 13 so it wasnt the coolest movie in the world to me.It is a movie i would buy for my little brother who is 3.my favorite charecter was Gill, voiced by willem dafoe.Who i think is a great actor.i would not recommend this to teens.only to little kids and maybe adults.
