I saw this movie with my mom, and now we're always quoting lines from it. It's hilarious. A great movie for the whole family. It's not just great for kids, but it's great for adults too. If you go to see it, you will love it! Hope you enjoy it!

reviews.review_title: Finding Nemo is an amazing film.
reviews.content: Finding Nemo is a very well done movie. The graphics are incredible, the characters are funny, and its a great story. Although it may leave some children under 4 traumatized,(between the angry sharks, exploding mines, and the barracuda attack)it is a great movie for all ages except toddlers.

reviews.review_title: The best movie from Pixar to date
reviews.content: Finding Nemo was the best movie produced at Pixar studios to date. I am so glad this company didn't go under. this movie had enough of everything to keep you interested the entire time. Bruce was my favorite character, but only by a little over Crush.

OK, I am thirteen years old. I had no intention of seeing Finding Nemo. However, my little sister decided that she wanted to and asked if I wanted to go too. I probably wouldn't have gone, except that the last two Disney movies I had seen (Monsters Inc. and Lilo & Stitch) had actually been pretty good. Those I had seen on DVD, so this time I decided to see it in theatres.Let me tell you, I am SOOOOO glad I went! The animation was AWESOME- I have never seen water portrayed so realistically in an animated film before. The storyline was great too, not so many sad moments that it killed the film but not so many funny parts that half the movie was completely pointless to the plot. Plus, you've got your suspenseful OMG-a-shark-is-chasing-me scene, gotta love that. The characters were fun to watch but not too cutesy, as I had expected a Disney/Pixar movie about fish to be.All I have to add is, Finding Nemo has officially beat Monsters, Inc. as my favorite Disney movie. I am soooo going to get it on DVD Go see it soon!

going along with all the other reviews, all I can say is WOW!!! Pixar/Disney has a MASTERPIECE here. We do not go to the movies very often because of the prices nowadays (looking at around 30-35 bucks for a family of 3- refreshments included). So when we go, We are very picky about the movies we see. my wife and son wanted to see Nemo. I was wanting to see something else. I gave in and wasn't expecting much. cmon it's a kids movie. Boy, was I WRONG!!! This is by far the best movie we've watched in years. I was completely  impressed. The visuals are outstanding and the characters different personalities are great. The movie kept my son (4) attentive throughout (something that hasn't happened much). Usually it's the "dad i need a drink, dad i gotta go to the bathroom, dad I want my toys". Not this one. And I think it relates to kids and adults alike. Very funny and has subtle messages. 1.Nemo taking his disability in stride. 2.Parents have to let their kids grow up and explore. This movie hit home several times. Even though I hate to admit it, I actually got a little choked up when Marlin and Nemo finally got back together. That's how involved in the film you'll get. Do Not Let the chance to see Finding Nemo pass you by. Trust me, you'll love it. Money very well spent. We're going back to watch it again this weekend. and will DEFINITELY add this one to the DVD collection when its released. ABSOLUTELY Five stars!!!!!!!!      5/5

(give aways... if not seen movie, do not read b/c i say stuff from movie)hey! I think this is an amazing movie. It is sooo adorable. I love the way they did animation with the water and everything. These actors put so much into this work, as you can see, they made it work. It just shows in the production. I cried.. lol go figure. It just got me so touchy at the beginning... how after there were all those eggs, that stupid shark ate them all, and coral.. ohhh my poooor coral. i felt soo bad for marlin. Nemo was the last one who survived so obviously you'd guess that marlin would be cautious for his only baby. Then when nemo got caught by those divers... grrr i'm seriously never going fishing again i felt so bad after all those times i go fishing and awwww poor nemo gets stuck in a DENTIST'S OFFICE! poor poor nemo. My favorite character was probably crush, the turtle. and I thought that was soo cute with the whole "how old did a turtle get" with nemo and his dad. I also liked dory... I really had a feeling that dory and marlin were gonna hook up or something, but i guess marlin just wasn't "attracted" to this short-termed memory fish. And i thought that was sooo funny how she remembered everything after nemo said something to her towards the end and then they found marlin, then dory needed help.. geeze these characters got into a lot of mischief! My favorite scene was probably with the whole "talking whale." after all that with dory, and then marlin trying to talk whale "gee i wish i could talk whale" lol. Well to wrap this up, i'd like to ask a question.. after Gill and all them escaped from the denists office.. how the hell did they get out of the bags? i saw this with my boyfriend and when gill proposed his idea thats the first thing i said "how are they gonna get out of the bags?" It's like, impossible for them to. They'd die! awww poor gill... his dream... well thats all i'm gonna say. I just have to say that i loved this movie. It made me laugh, and it made me cry. well.. ok then.. bye

reviews.review_title: Great animation, great characters, great movie indeed.
reviews.content: Pixal most often presents us their great animated feature films and 'Finding Nemo' is no exception, rather is one of the best movies by them. Being one of a huge fan of animated movies myself, I certainly have enjoyed watching every second of the movie. The stunning animation, flawless story-line, and amusing humor will hardly make anyone not love the movie.Nemo (Alexander Gould), the only son that remains out of the 400 eggs laid by Marlin's (Albert Brooks) wife, is very excited about going to school for the very first time. But Marlin is very overprotective of his son and is still not ready to introduce Nemo to little more diverse or as per Marlin's though more dangerous than much safer home. Meanwhile, Nemo is more than ready to go to the school. During school, when Marlin tries to forbid his son to go to the unsafe areas, Nemo, who has been already mad at his father disobeys and go little too far and ends up getting caught by a human. Thus begins the journey of Marlin to find his son Nemo.No journey is exciting without a friend alongside. So the movie definitely provides one to Marlin, a sweet innocent friend dory (Ellen DeGeneres), a fish with short-term memory loss, on the way to catch the boat that took Nemo. They begin the journey together, which is full of adventure and thrill. Along with the risk of the vast ocean, Marlin also encounters the good side of the ocean. Those helping fins of the sea turtles, never separating company of dory, Nemo's tank buddies helping him get out of the aquarium and even the bad sharks trying to be nice with their little club with the slogan "Fish are friends not food" are some examples. The modern world of humans actually lacks these qualities and "Finding Nemo" definitely remains us about those duties.Disney always delivers the stories that tell the kids to be nice and helpful. This movie, however tells both kids and adults to be as such. Not forgetting to mention about the profound love between a father and his son, a simple story-line about the venture of a father to find his beloved son teaches us a lot.

I think this movie is the best movie i've seen in the whole year. I really like the animation and the story.. even though a lot of people said it's for kids but i think there something deep and meaningful about the whole thing. I love the character Dory.. so funny.. Anyway I think it's a very good family movie like other Pixar movie. I love it so much that i can say that people who said that it's a stupid pointless movie are stupid themselves.

I loved the movie, funny bits but also well known Disney sweetness and heartache. Even though I loved the movie I think they should stop give human emotions to animals, it only causes animal tragedy. Maybe they could make a movie about a made up animal or get a prehistoric animal. Sooner or later they start with alligators and every kid in the world would want a alligator. After the alligators are well fed on kids guess how much work the plummers will have when parents flush the 'gators down the toilet.

You'd be better off watching Toy Story in the animation category than this, which is a beautiful piece of computer animation, but bland in terms of dialogue particularly.  It's actually rather annoying.  And it lacks humor in my opinion.

Wow, this movie was the best animated film I've ever seen in my life. The animation was excellent, the voices were very energetic, and the characters were hilarious! There was Marlin, who is way too overprotective, there was Dory, who has short-term memory loss, and there were so many funny fish in that movie. The story is charming with some humorous parts. I correct myself: it was all funny! While I don't understand why it couldn't talk, the deep-sea anglerfish actually did scare some people. I think everything was exactly how the directors wanted it and if it wasn't, it turned out excellent anyways. I think that whoever hasn't seen this film should see it immediately!

reviews.review_title: Adventurous, fun, emotional and narratively perfect.
reviews.content: When I was younger, and I watched this movie numerous times, I understood that it was one of those few animated films that made me feel immersed in an adventurous world, full of characteristics close to human. All this through a story of ... FISH.That, ladies and gentlemen, is difficult to achieve in any story, and to date, after almost 15 years, the film still has the same effect on me.Thanks to this epic family drama, I was able to approach the work of greats like Pixar, the ingenious Thomas Newman, the fascinating and inspiring Lee Unkrich, and why not, a John Lasseter and an Andrew Stanton and a huge team of talented people. People who are able to bring stories with little appeal to great stories that are stored in the permanent mind of thousands of people.There is no doubt that visual beauty is not far behind. In fact, that is what makes the film even more attractive, and to this day, it still looks impressive, even with all the great technological advances that exist in the animation and technology film industry.Undoubtedly, Finding Nemo, will go to the cult cinema in the very near future as did Toy Story.

reviews.review_title: best animated film i have ever seen
reviews.content: An animated film, on the life in the ocean. This was the film I was waiting for. Hats off to Pixar studio, for making such an amazing film. They explored a whole lot of space left in the world the ocean. An also a story about a father who is in search of his son, it sounds a little schmaltzy, but you will love this emotion when you watch the film Marlin is the father who is in search of his son Nemo. His son is trapped by the fishermen and is now in an aquarium in a dentist's room.All the characters in the fish tank were amazing The most amazing fish (character) was Dory who helps Marlin in finding her son. And the fun part is that she has a short term memory loss. This added the funny flavor to the film. And the sharks who take an oath that they will never eat a fish were the funniest of them all. This film is for everybody in the family. I rate this film 9/10

reviews.review_title: This movie really blows everything out of the water!
reviews.content: This Pixar film, I believe, really gone and done it. I truly think they made a 101% job on Finding Nemo. It's funny for all ages, it's emotional, the morals spill out plain to see, it's adventurous, the film is top notch state of the art, and it's original. It really inspired me, and I've been coming up with stories all my life. I never thought to create a story about fish parenting in the ocean. I personally think it's so good that all animation movies should be compared to Finding Nemo before and after release. It was a top box hit, and full of extras as well. Pixar is really reeling in the cash. It was a jackpot of a film, and it will be extremely hard to make another film that will size up to it or even beat Finding Nemo. Of course with tomorrows technology I could see that happening in the next few years. Go see it if for some reason you haven't already.

Wow Finding Nemo is a great film for kids and adults. The characters are great! Definitely Dory!. I find that this movie has quite a few dark scenes especially the shark can be quite scary to younger kids. Nemo ends up in the tank gang who are all wonderful characters. The colours and animation were a perfect match to this film.I give this film a 10 out of 10 because i really liked it, and i recommend it for adults and kids of all ages although some scenes are a bit dark and its a bit sad at the start. Kids will love Dory as i did! and the other characters!.
Finding Nemo is a pleasant, fun, and yet very touching film about a father and son. The animation still looks wonderful many years later and is a great addition to Pixar's lineup of films.

I hated this movie!! It was awful!! I wish I woulda saved my money so now Iwould probably have money now to go see a cool movie, like Spider-Man 2..even though I saw Spidey 2 times :-D but anyway I think that Finding Nemo is the kind of movie you can only watch once or twice then you get sick of it. Thats my opinion anyway. It was so dumb and childish.... even though I'm sorta a kid my self, I'm 13 and I still thought it was really dumb. Just keep swimming, just keep swimming... that stupid song was stuck in my head all night after I saw that movie! And the whole "We are friendly sharks, we don't eat fish" thing was really really stupid.

I saw this movie on the opening night with my daughter and nephew (both 3-year-olds), and I found that I was shushing them more so I could hear the movie rather than worrying about others hearing them. This is the funniest animated film I have seen since Toy Story. It's definitely worth seeing. You'll be laughing the whole way through the film!

I have to admit that I expected to be bowled over by this film, but although it was gorgeous to look at and quite amusing from time to time, it never really gripped me. I didn't really feel any great tension or emotion, despite the fact that I took my young son, who also had just started school. In fact he was even less thrilled with it than I was, as 10 minutes from the end he wanted to leave and I had to persuade him to stay to the end. No surprise then that his preferred animated films are still Shrek, Monsters Inc and A Bug's Life.

reviews.review_title: Not quite Monsters Inc. but entertaining nonetheless
reviews.content: Pixar does it again! Although Finding Nemo lacks the wackiness and quirkiness of Monsters Inc, it is nonetheless an entertaining and ultimately satisfying animated film. The intelligent animation and interesting dialogue helps lift an otherwise predictable and cliched plot into something engrossing. Well worth the price of the movie ticket!The short animated filmlet at the start of the movie is really good and is an added bonus!

Since it was hard to imagine Pixar ever topping its original Toy Story, and upon first learning on who was going to provide the voices of the characters, I was not enthusiastic about Finding Nemo. None of the other Pixar releases (Bug's Life, Toy Story 2, Monsters Inc.) quite measured up to the original Toy Story, so I had reduced Nemo to rental status. It took a sold out show of Pirates of the Caribbean to make me experience one of the most enjoyable movies I have had the pleasure of watching on the big screen. There are movies that can be enjoyed equally on the theaters or at home, and there are others that you just have to shell out the 8 or so dollars and watch it on theater, and Finding Nemo is definitely one of the latter.The computer recreation of water and light should in itself amaze you. I know it did to me. The way sand floats, how light shines through rippling water, how algae looks in a dirty aquarium...all recreated in a way that exceeded any expectations I may have had. The story, albeit simplistic in form, is touching and quick paced. The movie never feels like it is an hour and forty minutes long, and that is because Nemo has what I consider one of the best voiced over animated character ever in movie cinema. Never in my wildest dreams would I have thought that Ellen DeGeneres, whom I never cared for as an actor, could match, and even toppled Woody Allen's comedic delivery as Z in ANTZ, but she delivers the goods, and then some. As the voice of the memory lacking Dory, DeGeneres performance is truly worthy of recognition. Add the amazing way the animators converted DeGeneres excellent voice performance into animated facial expression on Dory, and you have one exquisite character. She is truly the highlight of the film.Funny, addictive, surprising, mesmerizing, Finding Nemo has the substance to please both young and old alike. Just be sure you experience Nemo on a theater...you will be sorry if you don't.

reviews.review_title: 10 Stars. More clever than Toy Story & Monsters, Inc.
reviews.content: Played to a packed Saturday matinee. Audience applauded at end. Clever, fun and entertaining, with few slow spots in the plot, our adults and kids enjoyed Finding Nemo very much. We guessed that Disney/Pixar was going to release this in Early December 2003 for Christmas Video/DVD sales - and it will be one of the hottest gift items for Xmas 2003.Roger Ebert review is very accurate, and I would classify Nemo as a "must see" type of movie.

Finding Nemo was one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. It is right up there, as far as I am concerned with Shrek, Monsters Inc., and Ice Age. Being a biology student at St. FX university, I found the little science related jokes to be great "... with fronds like these who need anenomes?".  I highly recommend this movie, it had a great story and had many funny moments throughout.

Words cannot begin to describe the visual graphic details of this movie. The lush backdrop of the ocean combined with the vivid colors of the characters makes this a treat for the eyes.Pixar has yet to disappoint!

reviews.review_title: Great Family Movie - but take care with small children!
reviews.content: Possible SpoilerOur whole family loved this movie. The animation was fantastic!There were inside jokes for the adults and the kids, plus several lines that have found their way into my kids language - like the gulls 'Mine? Mine?' when they are trying to scavenge from the pelicans.One thing - the scenes with Bruce the shark and his friends might be a bit intense for the preschool and younger elementary kids. Although they protest 'fish are friends, not food', there is a scary scene where Bruce looses it and chases Dory and Marlin, trying to eat them. My 6-year-old had a nightmare about sharks after that one.Scary part aside, the movie is destined to be a classic with the other Pixar movies.  Make sure you stay through the credits and look for familiar characters!

reviews.review_title: Another world (and, finally, the movie that gets us there)
reviews.content: I think that some of the more recent box-office successes have been attractive because they have been able to transport people out of this hectic world into some other place.  These movies, such as the original Star Wars Trilogy, the first Matrix movie, The Lord of the Rings, and others, have created this escape in enough depth and detail such that the viewer feels fully removed from their actual surroundings.Only a handful of these movies though, can take the audience somewhere else and still deal with real-world issues, all at once.  Finding Nemo is one of these movies.  And believe me, this "other world" is like nothing you've ever seen on the big screen.Pixar has out-done everyone, INCLUDING themselves.  Finding Nemo's underwater world is on the one hand distant and mysterious and on the other distinguishable and realistic.  The ocean setting has allowed Pixar to really let loose -- with amazing canvases of brilliant color, a shimmering, shifting, particulate-filled sea, and some of the best drawn non-human characters ever.  In Finding Nemo there is a wonderful paradox:  a far-away world that you can actually visit when you leave the theater.But Finding Nemo's fantasy and reality two-step doesn't stop with the animation.  The story takes that same theme.  The characters -- a family of clown fish, a blue tang, a posse of sharks, pelicans, crazy seagulls, and the demonic dentist's daughter -- add a sense of fantasy and humor.  But their trials -- the young one finding himself, a father's struggle against loss, the lonely one's sense of need, and the elder's desire to break free from his trapped life -- are real-world, everyday issues.  And, in typical Disney fashion, the movie is moved along by an epic quest that brings all of these disparate pieces together.  Everything in Finding Nemo is allegorical, and although the story line itself is not as creative as some show-stopping narrative like Requiem for a Dream, the way the script relates to both the characters at the fantasy level and the audience at the reality level is novel and inspiring.Despite some of my roommates' skepticism, I wanted to see this movie from the moment I first heard the concept.  For me -- that's some hype to live up to.  But unlike the sequels in the Matrix and Star Wars series, Finding Nemo delivers -- a fantasy / reality combination that I hope won't soon be forgotten. 10/10

Disney didn't seem to be delivering the goods like they used to until Nemo came along and boy was he worth the wait. I never thought the clown fish can be so sweet. Finding Nemo is a great family film enjoyed by all. When watching it you'll find that at least two people will come out trying to speak whale or quoting 'Fish are friend, not Food' but that's what makes the film so great and memorable. If you have not seen the film yet - Where have you been? You'll fall completely in love with all of the characters and insist that you buy your own aquarium for your own Nemo cast. I hope that Disney's next project is a good as 'Finding Nemo' - Good Luck.
One of the greatest movies of all time. It's hard to find someone who did not watch this iconic feature

First of all, I loved this movie. Thought everything was well designed and freakin' hilarious. It did lead me to an observation that I find intriguing. Why is it that probably 90% of Disney movies center on characters who are either orphans or have lost one or the other of their parents? Think about it. Name 5 disney movies, and I mean originals (non of those crappy sequels), that have characters with both of their parents. It's tough isn't it? Why does Disney do this? Does it help audiences sympathize with the characters more? I don't know. If I was a parent I might be concerned for my kids. Watching these movies might lead them to believe that their parents are going to die and leave them in the uncapable hands of evil step mothers or something like that. I understand that many families today consist of single parent homes, but many of these movies have scenes or alude to the death of one or both parents. I don't know if anyone has some insight into why this is, but I find it interesting.

It's been seven years since Pixar unleashed Toy Story 2, the first full-length computer animated feature film, on the world, and what a wild, whimsical ride it was. Working in tandem with Disney (an association perilously close to ending), Pixar has provided several equally wondrous rides -- Toy Story 2, A Bug's Life, Monsters Inc., all of which contained themes and characters perfectly suited to the hyper-realistic computer-generated style of animation. Pixar's films feature carefully crafted narratives, simple but not simplistic, offering an ebb and flow of action-stoked set pieces that, at best, stoke our adrenaline while keeping our funny bones on vibrating overdrive.For it's 2003 release -- and perhaps greatest -- achievement, Pixar looks into the majestic depths of the ocean. The result -- Finding Nemo -- is a movie of extraordinary visual spectacle, astonishing emotional depth, and brilliant voice acting (Ellen deserved an Oscar nomination). It's every bit as inventive as the Toy Story franchise, every bit as charming as Bug's Life, every bit as colorful and vibrant as Monster's Inc. But it's even more compelling, more emotionally driven than these precursors. Everything, in a sense, has led up to Nemo, the best of all possible computer animated worlds.

reviews.review_title: The Best Animated Film of All Time
reviews.content: This 2003 triumph from Pixar - the outfit that gave us both "Toy Story" movies and "MonSters, Inc." - has a more emotionally substantial story than its predecessors, set against stunningly beautiful backgrounds that set a new high-water mark in the digital art form, surpassing even "Shrek," produced by Pixar's arch-rivals at PDI. This film proves Pixar reigns as the finest storytellers in family film. To create a grand odyssey for two lovable underdogs, the Pixar team mixes playfulness, a deep love of film, and a visual beauty that is unmatched in the industry. This is not just a great animated movie  it is a superior film, period.

Yes, it was THAT good!First off, the animation was superb. We are talking total immersion in this oceanic adventure. No pun intended. Okay, it was. But still.... The amount of detail to each individual fish, shark, whale, seagull, anemone and turtle is astounding. If not for the human-like facial expressions/exaggeration and characteristics you would almost think you were watching a National Geographic special. Only better! And the water! Of course you have to make it believable that you are watching a movie about being underwater...and they sell it. Very realistic and imaginative depiction of ocean life down to how the sunlight streams through the water.Okay, the eye-candy out of the way (wow, animation never looked so good!) the voice-acting is fantastic! Albert Brooks as Marlin (Nemo's Dad), Ellen DeGeneres stealing the show as Dory (she was extremely funny), and of course other big names like Geoffrey Rush, and Willem Dafoe and even Eric Bana of soon-to-be HULK fame lent their voice talents to this grand story.If you don't know the story by now, it's basically this: Nemo is a clown-fish that accidentally ends up being taken from his home. Marlin, his over-protective father sets off to search for him in the big blue, and along the way picks up help from very interesting characters along the way, not the least of which is Dory.During the first 15 minutes of the film you are introduced of course to the characters and then a tragedy occurs leading us to the events of having to find Nemo. Even though this film like all Disney fare, is intended for kids enjoyment, it has some grown-up themes and plenty of things for adults to enjoy. Pixar has demonstrated their ability to make a film on kids and adults level alike with their other efforts.I was surprised but how successful and seamless a story this was, considering that it was director Andrew Stanton's first time at the helm of a Pixar studio's film... but he has carried the tradition of perfection with flying colors. Most movies, animated and non-animated alike, usually never get it so right.The music is a superb mixture of orchestral music and appropriate tropical instrumental music to set the mood and tone of the story and it's various moments. Instead of Pixar favorite Randy Newman doing the score for yet another Pixar flick, the reins were handed to Thomas Newman, who is none other than Randy's cousin as well as the son of Alfred Newman, who is famous in his own right for his film scores before his death in 1970 resulting from emphysema. His (Alfred) most recognized work, and perhaps most insignificant, is the theme you hear during the FOX 20th Century studio trailers before one of their movies. At any rate, Thomas Newman has composed a fantastic score that sets the mood wonderfully, and yet never really stands out above the events of the movie. And why should it? The rendered animation is a sight to behold and carries the story well enough on it's own along with the stellar voice cast.I give this movie 10 stars!

Finding new life in the old fish-story, Finding Nemo is another fine computer animated offering from the people at Pixar, just as family-oriented as their last offerings, and just as adventure and humor-filled as ever. The animation and backgrounds are superb; it's often a remarkable achievement, and the colorful scenes of marine life and reefs makes it a visual treat. Though the film takes a little while to get going, after a truly heart-wrenching tragic beginning (at least for an animated film), once the search for Nemo starts, it's a non-stop quest with one clever thing after another. In fact, much like its previous siblings, the script is full of amusing situations (such as the chaotic climax at the dentist's office), clever dialogue, and humorous finds. It's also packed to the gills (pun intended) with eccentric characters, such as a trio of sharks trying to kick the habit of eating other fish, a pack of surfer-dude sea turtles, and some dim-witted birds. But the funniest bits are, of course, the myriad of dangers the poor fish must face, from a sea of jellyfish, to the threat of predators, to being swallowed up by a whale. The voice actors, from the neurotic Brooks to the spacey DeGeneres, are all terrific, and well chosen.

I was a big Finding Nemo fan. I should watch it again as an adult, but almost 20 years ago I was in love with this movie and watched it multiple times!Nemo had a loving father, which I didn't. And I always wanted a relationship with my father. Seeing them separated made it almost traumatic for me! I was praying for them to reunite the entire film! The way they captured the world under the sea was fantastic! The facts were so accurate and they taught children in a creative way! Seeing the passion nemos father possessed was inspiring in many ways. He didn't quit, and love took him a long way. I will never forget this movie. Its a life long classic in my opinion!

A film with joy, curiosity and excitement. swim with sharks and be inside a whale, it's quite a trip. it is a movie I can definitely recommend.find Nemo is a movie I saw as a kid, so it means a lot to me. the film also has some good messages e.g. family means a lot and one you should not take for granted.

Oh, my were do I begin, (smile), it was great. Nemo is fun to be with and you feel like a kid again. when you are really 30 something. ehehe well see it to believe, Pixar seems not to do wrong. OH, find Nemo in Monster Inc. somewhere? He's there, dude!

What needs to be said? Pixar hasn't made one bad movie yet. Every Pixar movie is an instant classic, and this is no exception. I can hardly wait for the DVD to come out so I can watch the bloopers and all the extras.
Pixar did an amazing job, with computer graphics, voice acting and every nuance of wit throughout the plot.

This is a great movie for people of all ages. We took the kids, but I'm going back on my own for a second time. Ellen DeGeneres is absolutely flawless and endearing.Proof positive that a fun and exciting movie need not resort to gratuitous sex or violence.

*SPOILERS*I went to see Finding Nemo last night. Right from the start with the bloody massacre of almost an entire family (including women and children) to the sharks with dodgy accents I was truly terrified. It dawned on me half way through the film what was really scary. The thought of a super intelligent aquatic creatures who have the ability to outsmart people makes me kind of sick with terror.

reviews.review_title: Heartwarming and beautifully animated, Finding Nemo is one of the best movies out there
reviews.content: Finding Nemo is, as far as I know, the first animated movie that has real value for adults as well as kids. And not in the way that most kid films do, that are merely bearable and faintly amusing at best to anyone above the age of 14. Finding Nemo has a couple of essentials for all age groups: for kids, there is the moral of the story, the cute and funny characters (think the albatros and the turtle), and of course the happy ending. For adolescents and grown-ups, there are contemporary movie references, and more 'grown-up' jokes that might be hard to grasp for little kids. The amazing animation is always a huge added bonus for anyone who really pays attention to the movie, and would be worth going to the movies for even if the story was only so-so and the dialogue boring. I know this whole age-group thing because after finally convincing my cousins, who are both boys (ages 10 and 12), to go with me, they watched it and actually enjoyed it. So did a very large part of people my age (16) and my parents have actually seen it twice. Finding Nemo is a truly great move, and perfect to watch when you don't want to see something complicated, but are more in the mood for something uplifting yet still with substance.9/10

You tend to get bored on an airplane. Not on my flight! From Amsterdam to New York takes about eight hrs, and I wasn't bored for a single minute. Cause they had all these cool movies to watch! So I started with the Matrix; Reloaded (not so good), followed by Finding Nemo.Those guys @ Pixar, how do they do it? They always seem to find a new angle and a complete different idea for their movies. For instance; Toy Story 2 was totaly different from TS1, although it features a lot of the same characters.And now this; Finding Nemo...I didnt really know what to expect; a fish searching for his lost son, who's been kidnapped by a dentist? But hey, its a Pixar movie, so its gotta be good, right?And so it was! I couldn't get that smile of my face, because this movie is hilarious! Starting with the totally new characters, the crazy storyline, and still it has that great "Pixar-feel" to it. Bright, vibrant colours, great voice acting, and -wow- beautifully animated (if that is correct English).This is another MustHave for my DVD collection!

reviews.review_title: Beautiful animation and Ellen is hilarious
reviews.content: Finding Nemo is a beautiful work of art. Ellen DeGeneres as Dory is fantastic in this film. The first time I heard Ellen's comedy was a routine that was played on an airplane about bad milk. She has such an interesting, quirky way of looking at the world and the writers of Finding Nemo captured that perfectly in the Dory's character. The animation is gorgeous. The color of the water and the way it changes as the characters swim through it is beautiful. Director Andrew Stanton is hilarious as Crush. What a talented guy. This movie has a great message for parents on good child-rearing and about taking chances and living even when life gives you a a setback like a tiny flipper.

reviews.review_title: No Phil Collins song, but lots of fishy fun.
reviews.content: I thought Pixar would struggle with the ocean but they have pulled it off. An absolutely fantastic storyline with amazing scenery and jokes that will keep you laughing every minute of the movie. My mum and dad loved it and so did my 4 year old god daughter. A movie definitely for all ages. The movie always provides laughter but a bit of sadness to go with it, but who doesn't want that in the storyline. The fish with the voice of Ellen is fantastic, the representation of Seagulls is also something you have to see. I advise...see it and buy it.

This film deserves an Oscar...Or at least deserves a nomination for an Academy Award.  Just when you thought PIXAR couldn't top Monsters Inc. They create this masterpiece.  It's amazing how far computer animations can go. It's the most visually stunning animated film ever made and how it touches people.  Who knew fish could show so much emotion.  I give this film 10 thumbs up if I had them. ;c)

reviews.review_title: Best film of the summer- maybe of the year....
reviews.content: I saw this movie and was totally blown away. The previews looked good, so I figured the movie would be decent. But I was not prepared at all for how incredibly the movie drew everyone in. When I saw it, it wasn't with an enormous amount of little kids, but with people of all ages- 3 to 75. The voice acting is some of the best  ever- especially Ellen DeGeneres. The character of Dory was taken to a whole other level by the quality of Ellen's voice work- you couldn't help but laugh hysterically at almost everything she said. However, she also proved she could do more than just comedy- I don't know how anyone cannot get the slightest bit misty when she says "I look at you, and....and I'm home..."  Other great voices by Albert Brooks (Marlin), Allison Janney (Peach), Willem Dafoe (Gil), Alexander Gould (Nemo) and Brad Garrett (Brother Blow) make this movie one of the funniest and feel good films I've seen in a long time. A shoo in for Best Animated Feature at the Oscars this year, and I can even see a nod for Best Picture.

reviews.review_title: Best animated movie I have ever seen- definitely worth seeing for anyone
reviews.content: I don't usually see animated movies in the theater, and when I do, I never see them a second time, except on video. However, this was the first exception. This immediately became my favorite animated movie, and I actually decided to go back and see it a second time. None of my friends who I saw it with the first time wanted to go back so I went with some others who hadn't yet seen it.As an 18-year-old, I know many kids my age pan animated movies as only for younger kids, and while this is true for many of them, there have been several that are good for anyone. One of the features I have noticed in Pixar movies (Monsters, Inc.; Toy Story; this) is that they direct the action towards younger kids, but add a number of lines that only an older audience will understand.Finding Nemo was excellent all around. Technically, it was incredibly well made- with realistic fish-like movements and equally realistic human-like facial expressions, not to mention the amazing aquatic scenery. The technical part actually added to the movie as a whole, making the characters more real, and therefore easier to relate to, despite the fact that they were fish. And then, of course, the plot and action of the film were great. It was funny, creative, and simply entertaining in general. The characters were likeable, the action was fast-moving, and the story was well-written. This will easily win best animated feature of 2003.In fact, the only criticism I have is not of the movie but of Pixar: since they did almost all the work in creating this film, it seems that they really don't need Disney as a distributor. They have already made enough of a name for themselves that without the backing of a giant motion-picture distributor, they could release the films themselves and produce the same amount of money- only they would be able to keep it all, instead of having to fork over huge portions to Disney.

I would estimate...about 97% of the movie going world loved this movie.However, I did not. I'm aware young children have higher pitched voices, but the particular children for supporting roles in this movies had voices I thought were going to bore into my brain.The story is simple. Nemo, a young fish who is the only survivor of his siblings is dared to go out into open water, and thus is captured. His overprotective father, who seems to have Nemo alone as remaining family, naturally, goes to look for him.From there, we're introduced to supporting characters who I found weren't much more than cheap laughs. Vegetarian sharks, ooh, that's original! All in all, the plot seems pretty much inconsequential to beautiful sweeping shots of the ocean and the coral reefs the fish call home. The scene with the jelly fish I found quite a treat to look at...but other than being yet another piece of eye candy that seems to be a trend nowadays....this movie has very little to offer.

I thought the movie was pleasant--I got a couple of chuckles.  I love the Toy Story movies, Shrek, Bug's Life, so with all the great reviews I was primed for a real laugher.  I just didn't laugh, though.  The whale talk got stale--fast, the 12 step shark program wasn't that funny.  I liked the seagulls, and I liked the Psycho reference.  Finally, I thought the most striking thing was that Marlin (the father) was the one expected to mature and let Nemo go.  Yet, if Nemo had listened to his father in the first place, he wouldn't have had to be found.

reviews.review_title: "Finding Nemo" will find a place in your heart.
reviews.content: The Movie "Finding Nemo" is a wholesome, heart-warming, feel-good tale about determination and love. According to National Geographic Magazine, when Andrew Stanton set out to make an animated children's movie set in the ocean and faithful to "the real rules of nature," all he needed was a perfect fish for his main character. Browsing through a coffee table book, his eyes landed on a photo of two fish peeking out of an anemoneand so a star was born. "Finding Nemo," the Pixar movie Stanton wrote and directed, won the 2003 Academy Award for best animated feature and, according to many sources, remains one of the highest grossing G-rated films of all time, taking in over $850 million dollars to date. And those are just a few of "Finding Nemo"s achievements. Others include the biggest opening weekend for any animated film upon its US release (30 May 2003), the bestselling DVD of all time in the world (as of January 2005) with 22 million copies sold (according to IMDb.com). "Finding Nemo" is ranked number 17 on the list of All-Time USA Box Office Receipts. One thing is clear: America loves this movie! "Finding Nemo" is a heart-warming, feel-good tale about, Nemo, a clown fish who lives in an anemone on a coral reef in the ocean with his overprotective father, Marlin (Nemo's mother is deceased). Nemo gets taken from his boyhood home by scuba divers from Sydney, Australia. An anxious and worried Marlin sets out on a quest through the ocean to find and rescue Nemo. Marlin meets up with Dori, a scatterbrained blue tang fish who suffers from short-term memory loss, who comes along for the ride. Their quest continues as the rest of the movie chronicles their adventures, including both setbacks and successes. It is hard to argue with the entertaining qualities of "Finding Nemo." The movie is pretty much hilarious. It is packed with almost non-stop action from one scene to the next. From the quips of Nemo's friends to the comments of Nigel the Pelican, there is never a dull moment in "Finding Nemo." Quotes like "P. Sherman, 42 Wallaby Way, Sydney," "Sharkbait! Hoo ha ha!" and "Mine, mine, mine!" have become links to our favorite movie memories. Also entertaining are both the music and graphics of "Finding Nemo." The music is moving while the graphics are stunning. It is as if you are really in an ocean. In addition to the movie's highly entertaining qualities, it is important to note that "Finding Nemo" is entertaining to a very broad audience. Adults and children alike thoroughly enjoy both the plot line and the visuals of the movie. The story is interesting enough for adults while still maintaining accessibility for youths; children get it and they love it. Many children have been influenced by this blockbuster hit. Just go to almost any aquarium and find the clown fish tank display; within minutes you will see and hear children come up to the tank shouting, "Nemo, Nemo, look there's Nemo!""Finding Nemo" is also attractive because it is relatable. It tells the poignant story of a father and son and their relationship. As an audience, we are touched by Marlin's protectiveness. We are scared for Nemo when he gets captured. We are glad when Marlin decides to look for Nemo. We are pulling for Marlin to find Nemo. And all of this is because we are relating to the story and its ties to our lives. The father/child or father/son relationship is such an important relationship to us as humans in our lives. Our fathers play vastly different roles in different people's lives. Some are near and involved, others are farther away and indifferent. Whether or not our fathers are around us or are very interested in our lives, almost all of us want to be able to interact with our fathers in some way, shape, or form. Thus, because of the universality with which we as humans connect with our fathers, we are pulling for Marlin and we want him to find Nemo. We can put ourselves in Nemo's shoes. We can relate because we would want our father to find us if we were Nemo.In addition to the previously mentioned qualities that make "Finding Nemo" stand out, the movie is wholesome. There are many family values that abound in the movie, such as portraying the father as a positive role model, never giving up when you have set your mind on something, and parents starting to let go of their children and send them on their way.The fact that Pixar shows the traditional family in such a positive light is really amazing. It is a computer-animated film, but anymore nowadays that does not guarantee that it will be good, clean fun. There have been other animated movies that have not been squeaky-clean. However, with "Finding Nemo" there is no need to worry because there is virtually nothing questionable in the movie. All in all, "Finding Nemo" is a fun, touching, and wholesome movie packed with family values. It is sure to delight you and your whole family. So take a dive into the ocean and enjoy "Finding Nemo."

Beside having excellent animation this movie seems to have a great research on ocean life. No it didnt seem national Geo program, it was all put in excellent story, animation, adventure and comedy. Loved watchin it

Finding Nemo is another great animated film by Pixar.  We took our kids to go watch it on opening night and they really enjoyed it.  Then again, they enjoyed Toy story 1 & 2, A Bugs Life, Monsters Inc., Shrek, Ice Age, and all the other CG films done by Pixar, Dreamworks and Fox.  I, myself, thought the movie was pretty darn funny at certain times... at others, touching. For a kids movie, I would give it 9 out of 10 stars.  So take your kids to go see the movie, they'll like it.

I was truly astounded by what I saw. The effects of the water and little background objects was amazing. On some levels it made Monsters, Inc. look ancient. The story was a typical "Have to find somebody" plot but it had a fresh take on it as the single parent made it more real. The thing that sets this movie apart from others is the secondary characters. Pixar really pays attention to getting these right. Sometimes they even overshadow the main characters they get to be so good. As always, lessons are learned and fun was had by all. After Jungle Book 2 and countless other run of the mill sequels Disney is pumping out, Pixar again shows that Disney needs lead or get out of the way. I generally rate a movie on the consumption of food. A lot of food eaten, it was bad. Hardly any food eaten, too good. So let's put it this way: My 6 year old sat transfixed and my 3 year old sat with his face on the seat in front of him watching. All the food consumed? 5 pieces of licorice. That's it. They were just far too busy watching to eat.

Perhaps you missed. It was quick, but the message was there. The slam on Americans. When Marlin was telling the group of sharks that divers had taken Nemo, the response was "Humans, they think they own everything." Then the comment, "Yeah, must be Americans." Excuse me Disney, but that offends me.  I am American and proud.  If you have a problem with this country take your films, parks, cable channels to another country and see if you make nearly as much money as here in America. Walt would be ashamed of what you've become.

Visuals were decent, but its nothing ground-breaking.  It doesn't make me go, "WOW" like toy story or monsters INC.  IMO monsters INC was more brilliant and a better movie, toy story 1 and 2 were better also. Finding Nemo was just really plain.  The ocean got really boring after a while, and the voice for Marlin the overprotective father was really annoying also.  He was shouting the whole movie, it just got really old. I felt disconnected and bored many times in the movie theatre.

I love these movies and Finding Nemo is incredible.One thing I thought was amazing was how the color saturation changed when moving from the ocean scenes to the aquarium. What incredible attention to detail!Pixar has another blockbuster family movie!

reviews.review_title: Good movie - some scenes not appropriate for young kids
reviews.content:
Loved the movie except the recurring theme in movies today where a few scenes are off topic.  If Pixar dropped the shark character andsequences, this would have been a perfect movie.  As it was, my seven year old was terrified for the first 5 minutes of the movie.
Beyond that, this was a clever movie with many wonderful scenes, gags and "one liners" that kept the kids well entertained.

Being a true fan of the Lion King, and having heard of this record breaking animated picture "Finding Nemo", I couldn't believe that this movie could touch me so much!!! I saw it in my English class and was thrilled by the photography, the colours, the voice acting (Willem Dafoe, Albert Brooks, etc), the characters, th script and the humor. I think that everything is perfect here and that Pixar has made it's greatest work since Toy Story, which was my favourite Pixar. It is so amazing how they used technology to make a movie like that, so warm, witty!!! And they didn't even forget the script!!!! A+ However, I don't consider it as my favourite Disney movie. My favourite is the Lio King, which is more perfect, brilliant and powerful, the voice acting is the best in animation history, the story is moving and it resembles so much to life in Africa. But I must say, these two movies blew me away!!!

A great animation! Pixar studios made one of their best films. The story of the film is interesting and thrilling, showing us a true love between father and son, despite the fact that they are clown-fishes. Many awesome jokes in the script, too. The genre's fans should watch it at all cost, I gave it 9/10.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely stunning, a faultless piece of entertainment
reviews.content: This film is quite simply a work of genius.  The quality of the animation is stunning, with the effects of waves, reflections, splashes, and underwater motion all perfectly realised.  The visual treat is perfectly complemented by a brilliant script that is easy to follow for youngsters, while being full of droll asides and references to keep the adults amused.  The idea that the sharks are in therapy to try and overcome their fish-eating tendencies, and the associated psycho-babble is one hilarious example. Another reviewer complained that the basic story is unoriginal, being yet another quest / journey of self-discovery.  Well I think younger kids need a simple plotline, and this film delivers it so well that any triteness never jars.  My daughter (nearly 5) was held in rapt attention throughout - and so were her mother and I. Highly recommended.

Just watched this little gem last night at the flicks.  It is another triumph for the guys at Pixar.  Fantastic animation, funny and moving in all the right parts.  Great little characters, and thats not just the main roles.  The turtle was definately a cool dude!!   Another note:  the short animation at the start (the one with the snowman in the globe) is one of the funniest things Ive seen in ages!  Classic, dont miss it!

This movie was exceptionally cute and appropriate for ALL ages!   We have a little girl who isn't even 1 year old yet, and we watched it with her and even she reacts and smiles and laughs at it and enjoys the colors and funny characters.   It has humor for all ages, as well.  Definitely a classic Disney/Pixar movie.

This was one of the most successful Disney films at the cinema to date. It is the underwater story of a young clown fish named Nemo (Alexander Gould) taken by divers and put into a tank. The idea is obviously his Dad, Marlin (Albert Brooks), and new friend Dory (Ellen DeGeneres), who has short-term memory loss, are "finding" him. Meanwhile, Nemo along with new friends including fishes Gill (Willem Dafoe), Bloat (Brad Garrett), Peach (Allison Janney), Gurgle (Austin Pendleton), Bubbles (Stephen Root), Deb/Flo (Vicki Lewis), Jacques (Joe Ranft) and pelican Nigel (Geoffrey Rush) are trying to escape. Along the journey Marland and Dory encounter three sharks, including Bruce (Barry Humphries, aka Dame Edna Everage) (named after the rubber Shark in the Jaws series), stinging jellyfish, turtles in a current tunnel, including "dude" Crush (Andrew Stanton) and much more, but he finds him eventually, and everything's fine. Also starring Big's Elizabeth Perkins as Coral, Nicholas Bird as Squirt, Bob Peterson as Mr. Ray, Eric Bana as Anchor, and Toy Story's John Ratzenberger as Fish School. It won the Oscar for Best Animated Feature, and it was nominated for Best Music, Original Score for Thomas Newman, Best Sound Editing, and Best Writing, Original Screenplay, it was nominated the BAFTA for Best Original Screenplay, and it was nominated the Golden Globe for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy. It was number 13 on The 100 Greatest Family Films.

First of all, let me tell you that I am not someone who just  hates all animated movies. Infact I love The Lion King, and recently the only good Disney animated movies are the one's Pixar has made, so I have nothing against Pixar. Both Toy Story and Toy Story 2 are great movies,(especially the first one), and A Bug's Life and Monsters Inc. are definitly a cut above the modern animated movie, but I have to say with disappointment that Finding Nemo is not anywhere near those good movies. Let me start with my biggest complaint, TOO MUCH ACTION! This movie had way too much action for an animated movie. Animated movies aren't about action, but I guess the filmmakers of this movie didn't know that. While I don't mind some action sequences in an animated movie,( like the antalope stampede in Lion King), the action sequences in this movie get a little redundent. I guess the animators are tring to "wow" you with the animation, and maybe that would of worked if this was the first movie of it's kind, but now that a lot of these type of movies have come out it's just boring. So then you may ask, what are animated movies about? Two things, laughter and fun, which this film is lacking in. While the other Pixar movies have fun jokes for kids and intelligent jokes for adults this film has none. Sure there maybe a few smart jokes about aquatic creatures in the beginning, but most of the time there is an oppertunity for a joke, they start an action sequence. In my opion, Finding Nemo is probably the most over rated animated movie of all-time.

Another great animation! Yipee! Finding nemo I would have to say one the best Disney films to come out since Monster's Inc,I was really surprised they have jokes that were funny to almost every everybody,it also has moral things like being kind to one other, sticking together,etc which I haven't seen so beautifully presented in family movie in a while. It's such a darn shame that Disney are selling Pixar(people who created this movie) to another company as Pixar and Finding Nemo are taking Disney to a whole new direction and telling people out there that Animation hasn't lost it's spark. It's a really great movie,buy it and enjoy it.

I love this movie so much. It's the best ever! It probably is my favorite movie of all time. So adorable, beautiful, and incomparable. I'm happy for Finding Nemo 2 even though The Incredibles is the only Pixar movie needing a part 2. I hope Finding Nemo 2 is as good or even better than Finding Nemo 1, although Pixar needs to make a part 2 for the movies really needing them, and it only appears that The Incredibles needs it because we didn't get to know what happened after the ending of The Incredibles since that movie did not have a perfectly happy ending. However, back to Finding Nemo, it is such a great movie. I always will love it. Best movie ever made!

I would like to congratulate Pixar studio for this movie, especially because story is so weak and has almost nothing in it. All the other Pixar movies before this had superb stories and now the trick was how did they made it click even then? One thing I have noticed that Pixar seem to have mastered the art of story telling. Realistic and state-of-the-art animation just add on to it. Good script is something that makes this movie work for every age group. I have seen it many times and found that some of these dialogs could still make me laugh.I will not say this is the best Pixar movie but it is different and of course it is a visual treat. Dialogues are superb. Characters are well defined and you just fall in love with them. A must for all animation lovers.

This is a great movie filled with beautiful visuals, wonderful voices, and a story that mimics life so heavily that I don't even think people can grasp it. Here you have Nemo, a fish who has a visible handicap (but not handicapping condition). His father, who lost his mate and whole brood (minus Nemo) wants to protect him with everything he has in him, yet Nemo just wants to be like everyone else and do what the other kids are doing. In the process of showing everyone what he can do by swimming further out over the drop than the other fish, he gets scooped up by a scuba diver and all of his father's nightmares come true: he's lost his only son.The story goes on to show what a parent will do for their child. In his quest to find his child, he runs into other sea life who all have their own disabilities, not all visual, but are able to help him in their own way. Each one of these characters have something very special about them, be it something that helps or hinders their life. They are all living "normal" lives in the big blue world of the ocean. From one character with short term memory loss, others with obsessive-compulsive disorders, they all have a limitation but don't let it limit their life.This movie punctuates how we think about physical differences and want to protect the people who have them yet everyone has some sort of difference, most of us who don't have it visible on our person. Each of us are able to accomplish great things, each of us have to overcome shortcomings in our lives and we all have some specialness, visible or not.

Great movie for kids and family. I was really nervous will Nemo find a way back home, but he did. I am very happy to watch this great movie again with friends. Pixar always make such a great movies. And this animation is something different. The amazing story in the sea. Dory is absolutely my favorite. So glad to watch finding Dory too. :)
Grew up watching this, I would watch it a lot, named my first pet after Nemo's dad. I have too much positive association with this film to rate it anything less.

reviews.review_title: one of the best animated movies
reviews.content: "Finding Nemo" is one of the best animated movies I've ever seen and one of the best Disney-Pixar movies. It's an amazing movie for the whole family. It's funny, colorful and ideal for both children and adults. With brilliant characters (like Dory),funny lines, unforgettable and captivating moments and scenes, "Finding Nemo" will never let you get bored. Disney and Pixar have create some believable characters that can be connected with us. "Finding Nemo" is a timeless and ,undoubtedly, an unforgettable movie that everyone should see. A huge cinematic success!My rating: 10/10

reviews.review_title: This is a movie about 2 fish who travel through the sea together with many adventures.
reviews.content: This was a nice and funny movie for kids. I love all of the different adventures they had as they swam through the sea. I recommend this for many of the young age children! Nemo and Dory are a great match and are really good friends. Dory sometimes gets on Nemo's nerves but they still stay close and hang in there together through the good and hard times.

reviews.review_title: Lovely because it is about the bonding of sea and surface creatures
reviews.content: Wow! This is one of the my most loving movie. Cause it's about the fishes and creatures under the sea. Also about the bonding with the sea creatures with the surface creatures. The voices are cool. Dory, Nemo and Marlin. Nemo is so cute. and the most cutest is dory. Although dory's voice is given by Ellen. And the latest part of Finding Dory is also such a wonderful movie. The movie at least you can watch with your family peacefully and that contains no violence or sex.
I remember watching Nemo as a kid, around 9 years old. I loved it then, and I love it now. My 3 children love it aswel. Such a timeless movie!

As a 16 year old, i think of myself as still a child in many ways! My love of Disney Films being one of them. However, i find Finding Nemo is one of a dying breed... a Disney film which is actually good. OK, no matter what Disney films will always be here to delight children, but there are few Disney films being produced at the moment that seem to hold parents and children alike. Now it seems that a lot of the time Disney are just cashing in. EVERYTHING has a sequel! And none of the sequels are half as good as the original. I think the Pixar/Disney collaboration has been good. As i said, Finding Nemo is an amazing Disney film that has many of the memorable characters and witty lines that makes it a film sure to be remembered for years to come. I think Disney should stick to the new ideas for movies. New Stories. You don't need to make 7 Lion King movies or Aladdin movies for kids to still love the characters. The Land Before Time film from Universal was quite probably one of if not my favourite film when i was a kid. Now you look at Sky movies and they are showing Land Before Time IX and even more! So i say keep making stand alone films with the quality, care and thought that you put into Finding Nemo and you'll remain a success forever.That's my two cents on that then! Hee hee x

While this movie is great and rated "G", be careful with the littlest ones, as there are some very exciting and scary scenes in it.  I spent some time in the lobby with my youngest(almost 3), although the other two were fine (5 and 7).As for the movie itself, it was brilliant...the story probably could have been a little deeper, but the scenery was some serious eye candy and Ellen DeGeneres stole the show.  My kids and I were all "speaking whale" on the way back to the car.

I took my kids (aged 6 and 8)to see this movie this afternoon expecting to spend the next two hours bored at best.  At worst, my kids would be as bored as well and I'd be spending that time trying to keep them under control. Not a chance!!!  This movie was great--not only for the kids but for me as well!  At times, we could barely hear the movie over all the laughing going on in the theatre.  I can't wait for this one to come out on DVD.  I gave Toy Story an 9/10 but this one was even better.  A clear 10/10!!

It was a very enjoyable experience.   Lots of layers for all ages. Visually stunning.Pixar has made many break throughs with each movie, with each having a quantum leap in something. The realistic water in Nemo is not quite as noticable as the leap of the fluffy/whispy fur in Monsters, but a big leap non the less.I loved all the nice inside jokes and homages.  I kept expecting a "Great Escape" homage with Gill, perhaps having his gimpy fin look like a ball glove or such, but I suppose some would have pointed out that Chicken Run already did it.  I did think that Gill's scar looked a lot like the facial scar in Platoon (problem being it was Tom Berenger's character that had the scar not Defoe's), but then again I might have been looking for way too inside jokes (how about a West Wing hint with the Star fish).
I just about wet myself when she started trying to speak Whaaaallllle.  I would have killed to have seen Ellen's face for real as she recorded those bits.

reviews.review_title: Finding Nemo is a great family film!!!!
reviews.content: Finding Nemo is a great movie for not only kids, but parents will not mind watching it either. It's a great family film. Finding Nemo is a heart warming tale about a clown fish named Nemo who gets separated from his Father, Marlin and his classmates after Nemo gets captured by a scuba diver. Throughout the movie, Marlin desperately tries to find his son with the help of a lovable fish named Dory. Dory tries to help but has short-term memory loss. This characteristic of her brings a lot of laughs into the movie. As Marlin tries to find Nemo and travel to Australia, where Nemo is taken, he encounters Bruce the shark, Crush the turtle, and many other lovable sea creatures along the way. I will not spoil it for you so to find out the ending, you'll have to watch it for yourself. I highly recommend that you watch this movie!!!

How are you suppose to find someone you care about, when there are so many fish in the sea? This question can be answered in the kids film, Finding Nemo by Disney Pixar. This adventurous film takes place in the ocean where the main characters are fish. The film really shows family issues and how it affects children of adolescence in a funny kids animation about a real serious issue. The fathers and sons relationship starts out edgy because of the issues in the family, but the father and the sons relationship starts to grow throughout the film. In the end there's almost always a solution to this, but nothing you would quite see in the film, Finding Nemo. When the film is done and over, you will see how this can affect a child and how there can be misunderstandings to every action. But in the end there's only one truth.The story starts out with the character Marlin and his wife, they are both clownfish. Marlin's wife dies by a tragic attack by a shark out in the open. His wife also laid a lot of eggs but after the shark attacked Marlin's wife, he took the eggs. There was only one left and this made the character Nemo, Marlin starts to get over protective with him because of what happened to his wife and the rest of his kids. But when Nemo starts to go to school he gets taken by divers. So Marlin sets out to find his son Nemo, he crosses by a fish named dory who suffers from short term memory loss. He goes with Dora and fights against many obstacles like sharks, jellyfish, and even seagulls. While nemo is trying to get out of a fish tank in a dentist's office.Now this isn't the best film in the world, it has its bad sides. For instance this isn't really that accurate of a film. The start of the story line starts out with the mom dying and the dad still living with his son and now the father has nobody and he's lonely. But the truth if the same situation happened in real life, the father would have turned female and the son would have mated with the now turned female. Then nemo would have turned female and would have to find a male mate. But instead this isn't accurate, they use a human interactive way. This is only one of the major things that aren't accurate if this situation happened in real life. But of course this film is a adventure/action, fiction story.I just want to say that this film is very interesting and has very many positive features in this film despite it not being very accurate to real life. There's so many lessons that kids can learn and also find it very entertaining at the same time. This film definitely shows family issues and how adolescents are affected by it. One way this is shown is by the father and sons relationship. In the film it shows right away at the beginning that the father doesn't want him to go to school while the son is insisting he goes on the first day, Nemo finally convinces his father to let him go. But the dad has to walk him there. This shows that the dad is very over protective over his son because he barely even allows him to go to his school. At some point in that scene he wouldn't even let nemo hangout with some people there. It really points out that there's family issues between the son and the father. Because nemo wants to go out and adventure while the father would just rather him stay safe and not go out. He wants this because he's afraid that he will lose his son if he isn't in his grasp. But all of that really connects with families with real issues like that because it can make them see all views and what's best to do about each situation. So it's a good learning experience in a great kids animation film.Characters really are the main part of the film. If it wasn't for the characters, the film wouldn't be a film. But it's not just characters that are important in how the characters are, it's what their identity is. If a film had a bad characters then the film wouldn't be that good and it would be a bad film. For instance, in Finding Nemo there's a scene where when Nemo is trapped in the fish tank and a bird comes in the dentist's office window and talks to the fish in the fish tank. About a rumor going around that Marlin is trying to find his lost son. Nemo hears about it and gets excited because he believes he's gonna be saved. Because of the characters in this certain scene it makes people understand better, it makes the film the way it is. Because of the bird spreading around the rumor because he does that a lot, the bird loves gossip. Nemo was able to find out that his dad was going to save him which means the characters were a big role in the film. This showed Marlins and Nemos relationship clearly and how he felt about his dad. Because of the characters and even side characters it gave you a real feel to the film and really showed how this was effecting Nemo.There's so much in this film, so many lessons hidden in the film through kids animation and child like characters. One of the main lessons was how a child of adolescents is affected by family issues. The way this is shown is by the characters and their development, and how it shows the father and sons relationship. The characters in the film are more child like and don't have anything that's inappropriate and even the animation is innocent. This and the father and son's relationship and what they say to each other shows how Nemo is affected and why he is the way he is. But in the end of the film it shows Marlin successfully getting his son back after almost failing and showing that he should never give up, and even saving Dora which he met on the way to find Nemo. There's a lesson on why you should never quit because if you don't you might even get what you want no matter how impossible it seems. But also it shows the father and sons relationship repaired and better than before. Because the family issues were resolved Nemo felt better and had a better life then with those family issues. This film was really great, it gave lessons for everyone on how you shouldn't quit and how a kid could be affected by family issues, and even how characters can be very important in a innocent animation.

I just watched "Finding Nemo" with my two-year-old son. (He wasn't even born when this movie came out, which is why I've never seen it until today). I really liked this film for a number of reasons. Not only was it very intense emotionally, but there was no point in the film was anything *bad* happening. There were no cheap innuendos, nothing but good clean fun. At the same time, it was never stupid or clownish (no pun intended). I would really like the creators of this film to know that I appreciated their work as being an effort in "using one's powers for good, not evil." In addition, I'm sure that people who have similar dilemmas in their family life: children with special needs, parents who are overprotective, or anyone with a loss or grief in their family, will feel especially attuned to this film. This is a great movie for either families or individuals.

reviews.review_title: "Finding Nemo" is a great example of the genius of the folks at Pixar.
reviews.content: I have always been a fan of animated movies and, starting with Toy Story, I've become increasingly impressed at what can be accomplished with computer animation. "Finding Nemo" is a great example of the genius of the folks at Pixar.The story is the parent-searches-for-lost-child plot in an aquatic setting. What is truly amazing is the artists' ability to turn fish into realistic characters. They carry all of the same kinds of insecurities and faults that humans do. Marlin's insecurity about becoming a parent comes back to slap him in the face during his fight with Nemo at the drop-off. The artists are able to convey expressions so well. Marlin's confusion when confronted with Dory's short-term memory problems is clearly communicated before he even opens his mouth to demand what's going on. The scars that you see on Gill  and later on Dory  are just an example of the level of detail achieved.The voice talent for this film is outstanding and greatly contributes to the believability of the characters. Albert Brooks is the perfect choice for the paranoid Marlin. The eternal optimist / mental sieve, Dory, is excellently voiced by Ellen DeGeneres. The voice of Gill, the scheming tribe leader of the fish tank, is provided by Willem Dafoe. The towering Brad Garrett is a fitting match for Bloat, the largest tank fish who needs assistance deflating after puffing himself up. Other actors lending their voices are Alexander Gould (Nemo), Elizabeth Perkins (Coral), Geoffrey Rush (Nigel), and John Ratzenberger (Fish School).Writer-director Andrew Stanton provides the voice of Crush, the 150-year-old sea turtle. The choice to give the sea turtles the attitudes and speech patterns of surfers was inspired. Life moves at a slower pace, and they ride the currents much like surfers ride the waves.The success of "Finding Nemo" is well-earned. It is clear that a great deal of thought went into the making of this movie. Everything from the characters to the environments was masterfully done.

Three years ago, Walt Disney Pictures and Pixar teamed up to release Finding Nemo to the masses. The hit children's underwater adventure video is an animated story based on a rebelliously independent young clownfish and his overprotective father's inability to let go. Enticed by a witty trailer and a captivating graphical design, Finding Nemo attracted a wide audience to the theatres. Digitally mastered and exquisitely written, Finding Nemo premiered May 3rd, 2003, as a G rated, light hearted, animated production geared towards children. The familiar voices of main characters, Dory (Ellen DeGeneres) and Marlin (Albert Brooks) teamed up in an encore partnership, returning from 1998's Dr. Dolittle. The hour and 44 minute presentation that brought over $300 million to the box office in its first week in the theatres. The script is a roller-coaster of friendly humor, written by Andrew Stanton and is sincerely thought provoking for Disney's adult viewers. Finding Nemo is sure to become a childhood classic. The opening scene is at Nemo's elementary school. Marlin, the widowed single parent, introduces Nemo to his teacher as a timid student, who requires extra attention for his special needs. Crowds will chuckle at the cynical humor, merciless mimicking students in the background and defining sarcastic gestures in this scene. Taunted by his peers, Nemo challenges his father, swimming farther and farther out into the abyss, towards a row boat at the surface. By the time Marlin catches his curiously disobedient son in the act, he swam far away from the group and was at the surface. The authors' creative expressiveness and ingenuity with the line "he touched the butt!" is innocent enough for six year olds to repeat, and at the same time harmlessly pokes fun at the daily trials parents face with young children. With the conscious lesson that every ill minded action has consequences, the row boat unexpectedly carries Nemo away from his home. Marlin enlists into a desperate rescue attempt for his beloved son and soon encounters Dory, the annoying travel companion with the funky problem of poor short term memory. In their travels, Marlin and Dory accidentally stumble upon two great white sharks. Instantly intrigued, Dory tries to make new friends, while Marlin backs off because of preconceived stereotypes about vicious great white sharks. As it turns out the two have joined to form an anti fish eating support group. With a membership pledge of "fish are friends, not food", Marlin and Dory escape a near death experience. In this fast paced scene that speaks to breaking stereotypes, adults will pick up on the parody on the politics of vegetarianism and a poke at "meaningless" support groups. Some of the content in this two minute scene may frighten younger viewers, as the loud noises, exploding mines and sharks with big scary teeth dominate the screen. Pressing on with the goal of finding his son in Sydney, Marlin and Dory ride the East Australian Current with a huge pack of sea turtles, and Marlin has a chance to tell his epic story. One of the elder turtles and an experienced parent, Crush (voice of Andrew Stanton) listens in, imparts some wisdom, and helps Marlin regain a firm a grasp on life. His advice, and the movie's main message, is that children are going to grow up and that part of successful parenting is letting them go and watching them. You have to know that you have done all you can for your children and that they have learned well. The climax of the movie is this scene, where Marlin realizes his error and finally begins to believe in his son. As the music tempo accelerates, the current quickens and the scene makes a dramatic switch back to a comedic tone, keeping children on the edge of their toes and leaving adults satisfied with the depth of content matter. Having arrived in Sydney, Marlin immediately jumps back into the search for his son. While the graphics change with the new on-land scenery, their impressive Pixar quality remains. New sounds from the city and music perfectly accompany every plot curve as the two fish face new challenges of human and bird interaction. A pelican named Nigel flies in to save the two fish from a particularly hungry flock of seagulls placing bids on their next meal, saying "Mine! Mine! Mine!" in their thick Australian brogue. The creative scripting is again paired with a hidden message of parenting that sometimes you need to take a risk and trust other people. Finding Nemo is a fantastic film, with much thought, enthusiasm and heart behind the plot, animation and message. Finding Nemo leaves Mom and Dad with a feeling of parental community in that they are not alone in their struggles with parenting. The innocent humor and narrative plot leaves children wanting to watch the movie several times over and quote their favorite lines with friends. The movie is appropriate for all children ages six and older and all adults who are young at heart. The underlying comedy and animation in this film hides a message that speaks of social issues, politics and parenting, which makes Finding Nemo a great movie for children and adults alike.
